acl.description: Sets and retrieves file ACL information.
body: acl
recursive: not required, default: false. # Recursively sets the specified ACL (added in Ansible 2.0). Incompatible with C(state=query).

default: not required, default: false. # if the target is a directory, setting this to yes will make it the default acl for entities created inside the directory. It causes an error if path is a file.
entity: not required, default: undefined. # actual user or group that the ACL applies to when matching entity types user or group are selected.
state: not required, default: query. # defines whether the ACL should be present or not.  The C(query) state gets the current acl without changing it, for use in 'register' operations.
follow: not required, default: true. # whether to follow symlinks on the path if a symlink is encountered.
etype: not required, default: null. # the entity type of the ACL to apply, see setfacl documentation for more info.

entry: not required, default: null. # DEPRECATED. The acl to set or remove.  This must always be quoted in the form of '<etype>:<qualifier>:<perms>'.  The qualifier may be empty for some types, but the type and perms are always required. '-' can be used as placeholder when you do not care about permissions. This is now superseded by entity, type and permissions fields.
path: required, default: null. # The full path of the file or object.
permissions: not required, default: null. # Permissions to apply/remove can be any combination of r, w and  x (read, write and execute respectively)

add_host.description: add a host (and alternatively a group) to the ansible-playbook in-memory inventory
body: add_host
name: required, default: undefined. # The hostname/ip of the host to add to the inventory, can include a colon and a port number.
groups: not required, default: undefined. # The groups to add the hostname to, comma separated.
airbrake_deployment
repo: not required, default: undefined. # URL of the project repository
environment: required, default: undefined. # The airbrake environment name, typically 'production', 'staging', etc.
token: required, default: undefined. # API token.
user: not required, default: undefined. # The username of the person doing the deployment
url: not required, default: https://airbrake.io/deploys.txt. # Optional URL to submit the notification to. Use to send notifications to Airbrake-compliant tools like Errbit.

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates for the target url will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
revision: not required, default: undefined. # A hash, number, tag, or other identifier showing what revision was deployed

aireos_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Cisco WLC
body: aireos_command

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote aireos device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.
aireos_config

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

diff_ignore_lines: not required, default: undefined. # Use this argument to specify one or more lines that should be ignored during the diff.  This is used for lines in the configuration that are automatically updated by the system.  This argument takes a list of regular expressions or exact line matches.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured. The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device run-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

diff_against: not required, default: undefined. # When using the C(ansible-playbook --diff) command line argument the module can generate diffs against different sources.,When this option is configured as I(intended), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the configuration provided in the C(intended_config) argument.,When this option is configured as I(running), the module will return the before and after diff of the running-config with respect to any changes made to the device configuration.

intended_config: not required, default: undefined. # The C(intended_config) provides the master configuration that the node should conform to and is used to check the final running-config against.   This argument will not modify any settings on the remote device and is strictly used to check the compliance of the current device's configuration against.  When specifying this argument, the task should also modify the C(diff_against) value and set it to I(intended).

running_config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(running_config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for comparison.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

save: not required, default: false. # The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line. If match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.
aix_inittab
action: required, default: undefined. # Action what the init has to do with this entry.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the entry should be present or absent in the inittab file
command: required, default: undefined. # What command has to run.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the inittab entry.
runlevel: required, default: undefined. # Runlevel of the entry.
insertafter: not required, default: undefined. # After which inittabline should the new entry inserted.
aix_lvol
pvs: not required, default: undefined. # Comma separated list of physical volumes e.g. C(hdisk1,hdisk2).
lv_type: not required, default: jfs2. # The type of the logical volume.
vg: required, default: undefined. # The volume group this logical volume is part of.
copies: not required, default: 1. # The number of copies of the logical volume. Maximum copies are 3.
lv: required, default: undefined. # The name of the logical volume.
state: not required, default: present. # Control if the logical volume exists. If C(present) and the volume does not already exist then the C(size) option is required.

policy: not required, default: maximum. # Sets the interphysical volume allocation policy. C(maximum) allocates logical partitions across the maximum number of physical volumes. C(minimum) allocates logical partitions across the minimum number of physical volumes.
opts: not required, default: undefined. # Free-form options to be passed to the mklv command.
size: not required, default: undefined. # The size of the logical volume with one of the [MGT] units.

alternatives.description: Manages alternative programs for common commands
body: alternatives
priority: not required, default: 50. # The priority of the alternative
path: required, default: undefined. # The path to the real executable that the link should point to.

link: not required, default: undefined. # The path to the symbolic link that should point to the real executable.,This option is always required on RHEL-based distributions. On Debian-based distributions this option is required when the alternative I(name) is unknown to the system.
name: required, default: undefined. # The generic name of the link.
aos_asn_pool
ranges: not required, default: undefined. # List of ASNs ranges to add to the ASN Pool. Each range must have 2 values.

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the ASN Pool to manage. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the ASN Pool (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the ASN Pool to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the ASN Pool to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
aos_blueprint
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Blueprint.
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.

reference_arch: not required, default: undefined. # When creating a blueprint, this value identifies a known AOS reference architecture value. I(Refer to AOS-server documentation for available values).
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Blueprint to manage. Only one of I(name) or I(id) can be set.
timeout: not required, default: 5. # When I(state=build-ready), this timeout identifies timeout in seconds to wait before declaring a failure.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the IP Pool to manage (can't be used to create a new IP Pool). Only one of I(name) or I(id) can be set.
template: not required, default: undefined. # When creating a blueprint, this value identifies, by name, an existing engineering design template within the AOS-server.
aos_blueprint_param
blueprint: required, default: undefined. # Blueprint Name or Id as defined in AOS.
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Blueprint Parameter (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.

name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of blueprint parameter, as defined by AOS design template. You can use the option I(get_param_list) to get the complete list of supported parameters for your blueprint.
get_param_list: not required, default: undefined. # Get the complete list of supported parameters for this blueprint and the description of those parameters.

value: not required, default: undefined. # Blueprint parameter value.  This value may be transformed by using the I(param_map) field; used when the blueprint parameter requires an AOS unique ID value.

param_map: not required, default: undefined. # Defines the aos-pyez collection that will is used to map the user-defined item name into the AOS unique ID value.  For example, if the caller provides an IP address pool I(param_value) called "Server-IpAddrs", then the aos-pyez collection is 'IpPools'. Some I(param_map) are already defined by default like I(logical_device_maps).
aos_blueprint_virtnet
blueprint: required, default: undefined. # Blueprint Name or Id as defined in AOS.

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the Virtual Network to manage. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Virtual Network (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of Virtual Network as part of the Blueprint.
aos_device
state: not required, default: normal. # Define in which state the device should be. Currently only I(normal) is supported but the goal is to add I(maint) and I(decomm).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # The device serial-number; i.e. uniquely identifies the device in the AOS system. Only one of I(name) or I(id) can be set.
approve: not required, default: no. # The approve argument instruct the module to convert a device in quarantine mode into approved mode.
id: not required, default: undefined. # The AOS internal id for a device; i.e. uniquely identifies the device in the AOS system. Only one of I(name) or I(id) can be set.
location: not required, default: undefined. # When approving a device using the I(approve) argument, it's possible define the location of the device.
aos_external_router

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the External Router to create. The format is defined by the I(content_format) parameter. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the External Router (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the External Router to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
loopback: not required, default: undefined. # IP address of the Loopback interface of the external_router.
asn: not required, default: undefined. # ASN id of the external_router.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the External Router to manage (can't be used to create a new External Router), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
aos_ip_pool

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the IP Pool to manage. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
subnets: not required, default: undefined. # List of subnet that needs to be part of the IP Pool.
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the IP Pool (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the IP Pool to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the IP Pool to manage (can't be used to create a new IP Pool), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
aos_logical_device

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the Logical Device to create. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Logical Device (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Logical Device to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the Logical Device to manage (can't be used to create a new Logical Device), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
aos_logical_device_map

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the Logical Device Map to manage. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value). Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Logical Device Map (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Logical Device Map to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the Logical Device Map to manage (can't be used to create a new Logical Device Map), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.

aos_login.description: Login to AOS server for session token
body: aos_login
passwd: not required, default: admin. # Password to use when connecting to the AOS server.
server: required, default: undefined. # Address of the AOS Server on which you want to open a connection.
user: not required, default: admin. # Login username to use when connecting to the AOS server.
port: not required, default: 443. # Port number to use when connecting to the AOS server.
aos_rack_type

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the Rack Type to create. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Rack Type (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Rack Type to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the Rack Type to manage (can't be used to create a new Rack Type), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(content) can be set.
aos_template

content: not required, default: undefined. # Datastructure of the Template to create. The data can be in YAML / JSON or directly a variable. It's the same datastructure that is returned on success in I(value).
state: not required, default: present. # Indicate what is the expected state of the Template (present or not).
session: required, default: undefined. # An existing AOS session as obtained by M(aos_login) module.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Template to manage. Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(src) can be set.
id: not required, default: undefined. # AOS Id of the Template to manage (can't be used to create a new Template), Only one of I(name), I(id) or I(src) can be set.

apache2_mod_proxy.description: Set and/or get members' attributes of an Apache httpd 2.4 mod_proxy balancer pool
body: apache2_mod_proxy
tls: not required, default: false. # Use https to access balancer management page.
balancer_vhost: required, default: None. # (ipv4|ipv6|fqdn):port of the Apache httpd 2.4 mod_proxy balancer pool.

member_host: not required, default: None. # (ipv4|ipv6|fqdn) of the balancer member to get or to set attributes to. Port number is autodetected and should not be specified here. If undefined, apache2_mod_proxy module will return a members list of dictionaries of all the current balancer pool members' attributes.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # Validate ssl/tls certificates.

state: not required, default: None. # Desired state of the member host. (absent|disabled),drained,hot_standby,ignore_errors can be simultaneously invoked by separating them with a comma (e.g. state=drained,ignore_errors).
balancer_url_suffix: not required, default: /balancer-manager/. # Suffix of the balancer pool url required to access the balancer pool status page (e.g. balancer_vhost[:port]/balancer_url_suffix).

apache2_module.description: enables/disables a module of the Apache2 webserver
body: apache2_module
state: not required, default: present. # indicate the desired state of the resource
force: not required, default: false. # force disabling of default modules and override Debian warnings
name: required, default: undefined. # name of the module to enable/disable
ignore_configcheck: not required, default: false. # Ignore configuration checks about inconsistent module configuration. Especially for mpm_* modules.
apk

available: not required, default: false. # During upgrade, reset versioned world dependencies and change logic to prefer replacing or downgrading packages (instead of holding them) if the currently installed package is no longer available from any repository.

state: not required, default: present. # Indicates the desired package(s) state.,C(present) ensures the package(s) is/are present.,C(absent) ensures the package(s) is/are absent.,C(latest) ensures the package(s) is/are present and the latest version(s).
upgrade: not required, default: false. # Upgrade all installed packages to their latest version.
update_cache: not required, default: false. # Update repository indexes. Can be run with other steps or on it's own.
name: not required, default: null. # A package name, like C(foo), or multiple packages, like C(foo, bar).
repository: not required, default: null. # A package repository or multiple repositories
apt

autoremove: not required, default: false. # If C(yes), remove unused dependency packages for all module states except I(build-dep). It can also be used as the only option.,Previous to version 2.4, autoclean was also an alias for autoremove, now it is its own separate command. See documentation for further information.
force: not required, default: no. # If C(yes), force installs/removes.
force_apt_get: not required, default: false. # Force usage of apt-get instead of aptitude
update_cache: not required, default: false. # Run the equivalent of C(apt-get update) before the operation. Can be run as part of the package installation or as a separate step.
only_upgrade: not required, default: false. # Only upgrade a package if it is already installed.
deb: not required, default: undefined. # Path to a .deb package on the remote machine.,If :// in the path, ansible will attempt to download deb before installing. (Version added 2.1)

cache_valid_time: not required, default: 0. # Update the apt cache if its older than the I(cache_valid_time). This option is set in seconds. As of Ansible 2.4, this implicitly sets I(update_cache) if set.

dpkg_options: not required, default: force-confdef,force-confold. # Add dpkg options to apt command. Defaults to '-o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef" -o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold"',Options should be supplied as comma separated list

upgrade: not required, default: no. # If yes or safe, performs an aptitude safe-upgrade.,If full, performs an aptitude full-upgrade.,If dist, performs an apt-get dist-upgrade.,Note: This does not upgrade a specific package, use state=latest for that.,Note: Since 2.4, apt-get is used as a fall-back if aptitude is not present.

name: not required, default: null. # A package name, like C(foo), or package specifier with version, like C(foo=1.0). Name wildcards (fnmatch) like C(apt*) and version wildcards like C(foo=1.0*) are also supported.  Note that the apt-get commandline supports implicit regex matches here but we do not because it can let typos through easier (If you typo C(foo) as C(fo) apt-get would install packages that have "fo" in their name with a warning and a prompt for the user.  Since we don't have warnings and prompts before installing we disallow this.  Use an explicit fnmatch pattern if you want wildcarding)
autoclean: not required, default: false. # If C(yes), cleans the local repository of retrieved package files that can no longer be downloaded.
purge: not required, default: false. # Will force purging of configuration files if the module state is set to I(absent).
allow_unauthenticated: not required, default: no. # Ignore if packages cannot be authenticated. This is useful for bootstrapping environments that manage their own apt-key setup.

state: not required, default: present. # Indicates the desired package state. C(latest) ensures that the latest version is installed. C(build-dep) ensures the package build dependencies are installed.
default_release: not required, default: null. # Corresponds to the C(-t) option for I(apt) and sets pin priorities

install_recommends: not required, default: null. # Corresponds to the C(--no-install-recommends) option for I(apt). C(yes) installs recommended packages.  C(no) does not install recommended packages. By default, Ansible will use the same defaults as the operating system. Suggested packages are never installed.

apt_key.description: Add or remove an apt key
body: apt_key
keyserver: not required, default: undefined. # The keyserver to retrieve key from.
url: not required, default: undefined. # The URL to retrieve key from.
data: not required, default: undefined. # The keyfile contents to add to the keyring.
keyring: not required, default: undefined. # -The path to specific keyring file in /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/
state: not required, default: present. # Ensures that the key is present (added) or absent (revoked).
file: not required, default: undefined. # The path to a keyfile on the remote server to add to the keyring.

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates for the target url will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

id: not required, default: undefined. # The identifier of the key.,Including this allows check mode to correctly report the changed state.,If specifying a subkey's id be aware that apt-key does not understand how to remove keys via a subkey id.  Specify the primary key's id instead.,This parameter is required when C(state) is set to C(absent).
apt_repository
repo: required, default: none. # A source string for the repository.
state: not required, default: present. # A source string state.
update_cache: not required, default: yes. # Run the equivalent of C(apt-get update) when a change occurs.  Cache updates are run after making changes.
mode: not required, default: 420. # The octal mode for newly created files in sources.list.d

codename: not required, default: undefined. # Override the distribution codename to use for PPA repositories. Should usually only be set when working with a PPA on a non-Ubuntu target (e.g. Debian or Mint)

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates for the target repo will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

filename: not required, default: undefined. # Sets the name of the source list file in sources.list.d. Defaults to a file name based on the repository source url. The .list extension will be automatically added.
apt_rpm
state: not required, default: present. # Indicates the desired package state
update_cache: not required, default: false. # update the package database first C(apt-get update).
pkg: required, default: null. # name of package to install, upgrade or remove.

archive.description: Creates a compressed archive of one or more files or trees.
body: archive
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
format: not required, default: gz. # The type of compression to use.

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
remove: not required, default: false. # Remove any added source files and trees after adding to archive.

dest: not required, default: null. # The file name of the destination archive. This is required when C(path) refers to multiple files by either specifying a glob, a directory or multiple paths in a list.
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
path: required, default: undefined. # Remote absolute path, glob, or list of paths or globs for the file or files to compress or archive.
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
exclude_path: not required, default: undefined. # Remote absolute path, glob, or list of paths or globs for the file or files to exclude from the archive

aruba_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Aruba Mobility Controller
body: aruba_command

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote aruba device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.
aruba_config

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

diff_ignore_lines: not required, default: undefined. # Use this argument to specify one or more lines that should be ignored during the diff.  This is used for lines in the configuration that are automatically updated by the system.  This argument takes a list of regular expressions or exact line matches.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

intended_config: not required, default: undefined. # The C(intended_config) provides the master configuration that the node should conform to and is used to check the final running-config against.   This argument will not modify any settings on the remote device and is strictly used to check the compliance of the current device's configuration against.  When specifying this argument, the task should also modify the C(diff_against) value and set it to I(intended).

diff_against: not required, default: undefined. # When using the C(ansible-playbook --diff) command line argument the module can generate diffs against different sources.,When this option is configure as I(startup), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the startup-config.,When this option is configured as I(intended), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the configuration provided in the C(intended_config) argument.,When this option is configured as I(running), the module will return the before and after diff of the running-config with respect to any changes made to the device configuration.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

running_config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(running_config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for comparison.

save_when: not required, default: never. # When changes are made to the device running-configuration, the changes are not copied to non-volatile storage by default.  Using this argument will change that before.  If the argument is set to I(always), then the running-config will always be copied to the startup-config and the I(modified) flag will always be set to True.  If the argument is set to I(modified), then the running-config will only be copied to the startup-config if it has changed since the last save to startup-config.  If the argument is set to I(never), the running-config will never be copied to the startup-config

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

asa_acl.description: Manage access-lists on a Cisco ASA
body: asa_acl

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

force: not required, default: false. # The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a changed needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines: required, default: undefined. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.
context: not required, default: null. # Specifies which context to target if you are running in the ASA in multiple context mode. Defaults to the current context you login to.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuruation to use as the base config for comparison.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  Finally if match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

asa_command.description: Run arbitrary commands on Cisco ASA devices
body: asa_command

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retires as expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
context: not required, default: null. # Specifies which context to target if you are running in the ASA in multiple context mode. Defaults to the current context you login to.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.

asa_config.description: Manage configuration sections on Cisco ASA devices
body: asa_config

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

passwords: not required, default: false. # This argument specifies to include passwords in the config when retrieving the running-config from the remote device.  This includes passwords related to VPN endpoints.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(defaults).

defaults: not required, default: false. # This argument specifies whether or not to collect all defaults when getting the remote device running config.  When enabled, the module will get the current config by issuing the command C(show running-config all).

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

update: not required, default: merge. # The I(update) argument controls how the configuration statements are processed on the remote device.  Valid choices for the I(update) argument are I(merge) and I(check).  When the argument is set to I(merge), the configuration changes are merged with the current device running configuration.  When the argument is set to I(check) the configuration updates are determined but not actually configured on the remote device.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

config: not required, default: null. # The C(config) argument allows the playbook designer to supply the base configuration to be used to validate configuration changes necessary.  If this argument is provided, the module will not download the running-config from the remote node.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.
context: not required, default: null. # Specifies which context to target if you are running in the ASA in multiple context mode. Defaults to the current context you login to.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

commit: not required, default: merge. # This argument specifies the update method to use when applying the configuration changes to the remote node.  If the value is set to I(merge) the configuration updates are merged with the running- config.  If the value is set to I(check), no changes are made to the remote host.

save: not required, default: false. # The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

assemble.description: Assembles a configuration file from fragments
body: assemble
remote_src: not required, default: True. # If False, it will search for src at originating/master machine, if True it will go to the remote/target machine for the src. Default is True.
dest: required, default: null. # A file to create using the concatenation of all of the source files.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
decrypt: not required, default: Yes. # This option controls the autodecryption of source files using vault.
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

regexp: not required, default: null. # Assemble files only if C(regex) matches the filename. If not set, all files are assembled. All "\" (backslash) must be escaped as "\\" to comply yaml syntax. Uses Python regular expressions; see U(http://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html).

validate: not required, default: null. # The validation command to run before copying into place.  The path to the file to validate is passed in via '%s' which must be present as in the sshd example below. The command is passed securely so shell features like expansion and pipes won't work.
ignore_hidden: not required, default: false. # A boolean that controls if files that start with a '.' will be included or not.
src: required, default: null. # An already existing directory full of source files.
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
delimiter: not required, default: null. # A delimiter to separate the file contents.

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
backup: not required, default: no. # Create a backup file (if C(yes)), including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.
assert
msg: not required, default: undefined. # The customized message used for a failing assertion
that: required, default: undefined. # A string expression of the same form that can be passed to the 'when' statement,Alternatively, a list of string expressions
async_status
jid: required, default: undefined. # Job or task identifier
mode: not required, default: status. # if C(status), obtain the status; if C(cleanup), clean up the async job cache located in C(~/.ansible_async/) for the specified job I(jid).

at.description: Schedule the execution of a command or script file via the at command.
body: at
count: required, default: undefined. # The count of units in the future to execute the command or script file.
state: not required, default: present. # The state dictates if the command or script file should be evaluated as present(added) or absent(deleted).
command: not required, default: null. # A command to be executed in the future.
units: required, default: undefined. # The type of units in the future to execute the command or script file.
unique: not required, default: false. # If a matching job is present a new job will not be added.
script_file: not required, default: null. # An existing script file to be executed in the future.

atomic_container.description: Manage the containers on the atomic host platform
body: atomic_container
state: required, default: latest. # State of the container

values: not required, default: None. # Values for the installation of the container.  This option is permitted only with mode 'user' or 'system'. The values specified here will be used at installation time as --set arguments for atomic install.
name: required, default: null. # Name of the container
rootfs: not required, default: null. # Define the rootfs of the image
image: required, default: null. # The image to use to install the container
backend: required, default: None. # Define the backend to use for the container
mode: required, default: None. # Define if it is an user or a system container
atomic_host
revision: not required, default: latest. # The version number of the atomic host to be deployed. Providing C(latest) will upgrade to the latest available version.

atomic_image.description: Manage the container images on the atomic host platform
body: atomic_image
started: not required, default: true. # Start or Stop the container

state: not required, default: latest. # The state of the container image.,The state C(latest) will ensure container image is upgraded to the latest version and forcefully restart container, if running.
name: required, default: null. # Name of the container image
backend: not required, default: None. # Define the backend where the image is pulled.

authorized_key.description: Adds or removes an SSH authorized key
body: authorized_key

comment: not required, default: None. # Change the comment on the public key. Rewriting the comment is useful in cases such as fetching it from GitHub or GitLab.,If no comment is specified, the existing comment will be kept.

exclusive: not required, default: no. # Whether to remove all other non-specified keys from the authorized_keys file. Multiple keys can be specified in a single C(key) string value by separating them by newlines.,This option is not loop aware, so if you use C(with_) , it will be exclusive per iteration of the loop, if you want multiple keys in the file you need to pass them all to C(key) in a single batch as mentioned above.
key_options: not required, default: null. # A string of ssh key options to be prepended to the key in the authorized_keys file
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the given key (with the given key_options) should or should not be in the file
user: required, default: undefined. # The username on the remote host whose authorized_keys file will be modified
key: required, default: undefined. # The SSH public key(s), as a string or (since 1.9) url (https://github.com/username.keys)
path: not required, default: (homedir)+/.ssh/authorized_keys. # Alternate path to the authorized_keys file

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # This only applies if using a https url as the source of the keys. If set to C(no), the SSL certificates will not be validated.,This should only set to C(no) used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates as it avoids verifying the source site.,Prior to 2.1 the code worked as if this was set to C(yes).

manage_dir: not required, default: yes. # Whether this module should manage the directory of the authorized key file.  If set, the module will create the directory, as well as set the owner and permissions of an existing directory. Be sure to set C(manage_dir=no) if you are using an alternate directory for authorized_keys, as set with C(path), since you could lock yourself out of SSH access. See the example below.

avi_actiongroupconfig.description: Module for setup of ActionGroupConfig Avi RESTful Object
body: avi_actiongroupconfig
username: not required, default: undefined. # Username used for accessing Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_USERNAME).
snmp_trap_profile_ref: not required, default: undefined. # Select the snmp trap notification to use when sending alerts via snmp trap.,It is a reference to an object of type snmptrapprofile.
description: not required, default: undefined. # User defined description for the object.

autoscale_trigger_notification: not required, default: undefined. # Trigger notification to autoscale manager.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as False.
controller: not required, default: undefined. # IP address or hostname of the controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_CONTROLLER).
external_only: required, default: undefined. # Generate alert only to external destinations.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as False.
email_config_ref: not required, default: undefined. # Select the email notification configuration to use when sending alerts via email.,It is a reference to an object of type alertemailconfig.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password of Avi user in Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_PASSWORD).
tenant: not required, default: admin. # Name of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Unique object identifier of the object.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the object.

level: required, default: undefined. # When an alert is generated, mark its priority via the alert level.,Enum options - ALERT_LOW, ALERT_MEDIUM, ALERT_HIGH.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as ALERT_LOW.
url: not required, default: undefined. # Avi controller URL of the object.
syslog_config_ref: not required, default: undefined. # Select the syslog notification configuration to use when sending alerts via syslog.,It is a reference to an object of type alertsyslogconfig.
tenant_ref: not required, default: undefined. # It is a reference to an object of type tenant.
action_script_config_ref: not required, default: undefined. # Reference of the action script configuration to be used.,It is a reference to an object of type alertscriptconfig.
state: not required, default: present. # The state that should be applied on the entity.
tenant_uuid: not required, default: . # UUID of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
api_version: not required, default: undefined. # Avi API version of to use for Avi API and objects.

VINETWORKSUBNETVMS,,VIDATASTORECONTENTS, VIMGRVCENTERCLOUDRUNTIME, VIVCENTERPORTGROUPS, VIVCENTERDATACENTERS, VIMGRHOSTRUNTIME, PLACEMENTGLOBALS, APICCONFIGURATION,,CIFTABLE, APICTRANSACTION, APICVMMDOMAINS, NSXCONFIGURATION, NSXSGTABLE,,NSXAGENTINTERNAL, NSXSGINFO, NSXSGIPS, NSXAGENTINTERNALCLI, MAXOBJECTS.
autoscale_alert: not required, default: undefined. # This alert config applies to auto scale alerts.
controller: not required, default: undefined. # IP address or hostname of the controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_CONTROLLER).
obj_uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Uuid of the resource for which alert was raised.
recommendation: not required, default: undefined. # Recommendation of alertconfig.

threshold: not required, default: undefined. # An alert is created only when the number of events meets or exceeds this number within the chosen time frame.,Allowed values are 1-65536.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as 1.

expiry_time: not required, default: undefined. # An alert is expired and deleted after the expiry time has elapsed.,The original event triggering the alert remains in the event's log.,Allowed values are 1-31536000.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as 86400.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password of Avi user in Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_PASSWORD).
tenant: not required, default: admin. # Name of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Unique object identifier of the object.

category: required, default: undefined. # Determines whether an alert is raised immediately when event occurs (realtime) or after specified number of events occurs within rolling time,window.,Enum options - REALTIME, ROLLINGWINDOW, WATERMARK.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as REALTIME.

throttle: not required, default: undefined. # Alerts are suppressed (throttled) for this duration of time since the last alert was raised for this alert config.,Allowed values are 0-31536000.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as 600.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the alert configuration.
url: not required, default: undefined. # Avi controller URL of the object.

enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Enable or disable this alert config from generating new alerts.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as True.
summary: not required, default: undefined. # Summary of reason why alert is generated.

rolling_window: not required, default: undefined. # Only if the number of events is reached or exceeded within the time window will an alert be generated.,Allowed values are 1-31536000.,Default value when not specified in API or module is interpreted by Avi Controller as 300.
source: required, default: undefined. # Signifies system events or the type of client logsused in this alert configuration.,Enum options - CONN_LOGS, APP_LOGS, EVENT_LOGS, METRICS.
state: not required, default: present. # The state that should be applied on the entity.
alert_rule: required, default: undefined. # List of filters matching on events or client logs used for triggering alerts.

action_group_ref: not required, default: undefined. # The alert config will trigger the selected alert action, which can send notifications and execute a controlscript.,It is a reference to an object of type actiongroupconfig.
tenant_uuid: not required, default: . # UUID of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
api_version: not required, default: undefined. # Avi API version of to use for Avi API and objects.

avi_alertemailconfig.description: Module for setup of AlertEmailConfig Avi RESTful Object

username: not required, default: undefined. # Username used for accessing Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_USERNAME).
uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Unique object identifier of the object.
to_emails: required, default: undefined. # Alerts are sent to the comma separated list of  email recipients.
description: not required, default: undefined. # User defined description for the object.
url: not required, default: undefined. # Avi controller URL of the object.
cc_emails: not required, default: undefined. # Alerts are copied to the comma separated list of  email recipients.
tenant_ref: not required, default: undefined. # It is a reference to an object of type tenant.
state: not required, default: present. # The state that should be applied on the entity.
controller: not required, default: undefined. # IP address or hostname of the controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_CONTROLLER).
api_version: not required, default: undefined. # Avi API version of to use for Avi API and objects.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password of Avi user in Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_PASSWORD).
tenant_uuid: not required, default: . # UUID of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
tenant: not required, default: admin. # Name of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
name: required, default: undefined. # A user-friendly name of the email notification service.

url: not required, default: undefined. # Avi controller URL of the object.
tenant_ref: not required, default: undefined. # It is a reference to an object of type tenant.
state: not required, default: present. # The state that should be applied on the entity.
name: required, default: undefined. # A user-friendly name of the script.
controller: not required, default: undefined. # IP address or hostname of the controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_CONTROLLER).
api_version: not required, default: undefined. # Avi API version of to use for Avi API and objects.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password of Avi user in Avi controller. The default value is the environment variable C(AVI_PASSWORD).
tenant_uuid: not required, default: . # UUID of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
tenant: not required, default: admin. # Name of tenant used for all Avi API calls and context of object.
uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Unique object identifier of the object.
