body: ec2_vpc_dhcp_option
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
dns_servers: not required, default: None. # A list of hosts to set the DNS servers for the VPC to. (Should be a list of IP addresses rather than host names.)
tags: not required, default: None. # Tags to be applied to a VPC options set if a new one is created, or if the resource_id is provided. (options must match)
ntp_servers: not required, default: None. # List of hosts to advertise as NTP servers for the VPC.

netbios_node_type: not required, default: None. # NetBIOS node type to advertise in the DHCP options. The AWS recommendation is to use 2 (when using netbios name services) http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_DHCP_Options.html

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.

inherit_existing: not required, default: false. # For any DHCP options not specified in these parameters, whether to inherit them from the options set already applied to vpc_id, or to reset them to be empty.
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.
domain_name: not required, default: None. # The domain name to set in the DHCP option sets

delete_old: not required, default: true. # Whether to delete the old VPC DHCP option set when associating a new one. This is primarily useful for debugging/development purposes when you want to quickly roll back to the old option set. Note that this setting will be ignored, and the old DHCP option set will be preserved, if it is in use by any other VPC. (Otherwise, AWS will return an error.)

state: not required, default: present. # create/assign or remove the DHCP options. If state is set to absent, then a DHCP options set matched either by id, or tags and options will be removed if possible.
vpc_id: not required, default: None. # VPC ID to associate with the requested DHCP option set. If no vpc id is provided, and no matching option set is found then a new DHCP option set is created.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

dhcp_options_id: not required, default: None. # The resource_id of an existing DHCP options set. If this is specified, then it will override other settings, except tags (which will be updated to match)
netbios_name_servers: not required, default: None. # List of hosts to advertise as NetBIOS servers.

ec2_vpc_vpn.description: Create, modify, and delete EC2 VPN connections.
body: ec2_vpc_vpn
connection_type: not required, default: ipsec.1. # The type of VPN connection.
customer_gateway_id: not required, default: undefined. # The ID of the customer gateway.
tags: not required, default: undefined. # Tags to attach to the VPN connection.
purge_tags: not required, default: false. # Whether or not to delete VPN connections tags that are associated with the connection but not specified in the task.
state: not required, default: present. # The desired state of the VPN connection.
purge_routes: not required, default: undefined. # Whether or not to delete VPN connections routes that are not specified in the task.
vpn_connection_id: not required, default: undefined. # The ID of the VPN connection. Required to modify or delete a connection if the filters option does not provide a unique match.

filters: not required, default: undefined. # An alternative to using vpn_connection_id. If multiple matches are found, vpn_connection_id is required. If one of the following suboptions is a list of items to filter by, only one item needs to match to find the VPN that correlates. e.g. if the filter 'cidr' is ['194.168.2.0/24', '192.168.2.0/24'] and the VPN route only has the destination cidr block of '192.168.2.0/24' it will be found with this filter (assuming there are not multiple VPNs that are matched). Another example, if the filter 'vpn' is equal to ['vpn-ccf7e7ad', 'vpn-cb0ae2a2'] and one of of the VPNs has the state deleted (exists but is unmodifiable) and the other exists and is not deleted, it will be found via this filter. See examples.
routes: not required, default: undefined. # Routes to add to the connection.
vpn_gateway_id: not required, default: undefined. # The ID of the virtual private gateway.
static_only: not required, default: false. # Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.

efs.description: create and maintain EFS file systems
body: efs
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.

name: not required, default: None. # Creation Token of Amazon EFS file system. Required for create. Either name or ID required for delete.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

tags: not required, default: None. # List of tags of Amazon EFS. Should be defined as dictionary In case of 'present' state with list of tags and existing EFS (matched by 'name'), tags of EFS will be replaced with provided data.
performance_mode: not required, default: general_purpose. # File system's performance mode to use. Only takes effect during creation.
id: not required, default: None. # ID of Amazon EFS. Either name or ID required for delete.
state: not required, default: present. # Allows to create, search and destroy Amazon EFS file system
wait_timeout: not required, default: 0. # How long the module should wait (in seconds) for desired state before returning. Zero means wait as long as necessary.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

targets: not required, default: None. # List of mounted targets. It should be a list of dictionaries, every dictionary should include next attributes: - subnet_id - Mandatory. The ID of the subnet to add the mount target in. - ip_address - Optional. A valid IPv4 address within the address range of the specified subnet. - security_groups - Optional. List of security group IDs, of the form 'sg-xxxxxxxx'. These must be for the same VPC as subnet specified This data may be modified for existing EFS using state 'present' and new list of mount targets.

wait: not required, default: no. # In case of 'present' state should wait for EFS 'available' life cycle state (of course, if current state not 'deleting' or 'deleted') In case of 'absent' state should wait for EFS 'deleted' life cycle state

enable_availability_zone: not required, default: true. # Whether to enable the availability zone of the instance on the target ELB if the availability zone has not already been enabled. If set to no, the task will fail if the availability zone is not enabled on the ELB.
ec2_elbs: not required, default: None. # List of ELB names, required for registration. The ec2_elbs fact should be used if there was a previous de-register.

elb_target_group.description: Manage a target group for an Application load balancer
body: elb_target_group
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
protocol: not required, default: undefined. # The protocol to use for routing traffic to the targets. Required when I(state) is C(present).
tags: not required, default: undefined. # A dictionary of one or more tags to assign to the target group.

purge_tags: not required, default: true. # If yes, existing tags will be purged from the resource to match exactly what is defined by I(tags) parameter. If the tag parameter is not set then tags will not be modified.
health_check_port: not required, default: The port on which each target receives traffic from the load balancer.. # The port the load balancer uses when performing health checks on targets.

successful_response_codes: not required, default: undefined. # The HTTP codes to use when checking for a successful response from a target. You can specify multiple values (for example, "200,202") or a range of values (for example, "200-299").

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
stickiness_type: not required, default: lb_cookie. # The type of sticky sessions. The possible value is lb_cookie.
modify_targets: not required, default: true. # Whether or not to alter existing targets in the group to match what is passed with the module
healthy_threshold_count: not required, default: undefined. # The number of consecutive health checks successes required before considering an unhealthy target healthy.

targets: not required, default: undefined. # A list of targets to assign to the target group. This parameter defaults to an empty list. Unless you set the 'modify_targets' parameter then all existing targets will be removed from the group. The list should be an Id and a Port parameter. See the Examples for detail.
health_check_path: not required, default: undefined. # The ping path that is the destination on the targets for health checks. The path must be defined in order to set a health check.
health_check_protocol: not required, default: undefined. # The protocol the load balancer uses when performing health checks on targets.
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
unhealthy_threshold_count: not required, default: undefined. # The number of consecutive health check failures required before considering a target unhealthy.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
health_check_interval: not required, default: undefined. # The approximate amount of time, in seconds, between health checks of an individual target.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the target group.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)

port: not required, default: undefined. # The port on which the targets receive traffic. This port is used unless you specify a port override when registering the target. Required if I(state) is C(present).

stickiness_lb_cookie_duration: not required, default: undefined. # The time period, in seconds, during which requests from a client should be routed to the same target. After this time period expires, the load balancer-generated cookie is considered stale. The range is 1 second to 1 week (604800 seconds).
state: required, default: undefined. # Create or destroy the target group.
stickiness_enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Indicates whether sticky sessions are enabled.
vpc_id: not required, default: undefined. # The identifier of the virtual private cloud (VPC). Required when I(state) is C(present).

deregistration_delay_timeout: not required, default: undefined. # The amount time for Elastic Load Balancing to wait before changing the state of a deregistering target from draining to unused. The range is 0-3600 seconds.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.
health_check_timeout: not required, default: undefined. # The amount of time, in seconds, during which no response from a target means a failed health check.

elb_target_group_facts.description: Gather facts about ELB target groups in AWS
body: elb_target_group_facts
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
load_balancer_arn: not required, default: undefined. # The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the load balancer.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)
target_group_arns: not required, default: undefined. # The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the target groups.
names: not required, default: undefined. # The names of the target groups.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

eos_banner.description: Manage multiline banners on Arista EOS devices
body: eos_banner

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
state: not required, default: present. # Specifies whether or not the configuration is present in the current devices active running configuration.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.
text: not required, default: null. # The banner text that should be present in the remote device running configuration.  This argument accepts a multiline string. Requires I(state=present).

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
banner: required, default: null. # Specifies which banner that should be configured on the remote device.

eos_command.description: Run arbitrary commands on an Arista EOS device
body: eos_command

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should be tried before it is considered failed.  The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditionals.

commands: required, default: undefined. # The commands to send to the remote EOS device over the configured provider.  The resulting output from the command is returned.  If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of I(retries) has been exceeded.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command.  If the command does not pass the specified conditional, the interval indicates how to long to wait before trying the command again.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # Specifies what to evaluate from the output of the command and what conditionals to apply.  This argument will cause the task to wait for a particular conditional to be true before moving forward.   If the conditional is not true by the configured retries, the task fails.  See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the I(wait_for) must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.
eos_config

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

force: not required, default: false. # The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.,Note this argument should be considered deprecated.  To achieve the equivalent, set the C(match=none) which is idempotent.  This argument will be removed in a future release.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

diff_against: not required, default: session. # When using the C(ansible-playbook --diff) command line argument the module can generate diffs against different sources.,When this option is configure as I(startup), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the startup-config.,When this option is configured as I(intended), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the configuration provided in the C(intended_config) argument.,When this option is configured as I(running), the module will return the before and after diff of the running-config with respect to any changes made to the device configuration.,When this option is configured as C(session), the diff returned will be based on the configuration session.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

running_config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(running_config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for this module.

diff_ignore_lines: not required, default: undefined. # Use this argument to specify one or more lines that should be ignored during the diff.  This is used for lines in the configuration that are automatically updated by the system.  This argument takes a list of regular expressions or exact line matches.

src: not required, default: null. # The I(src) argument provides a path to the configuration file to load into the remote system.  The path can either be a full system path to the configuration file if the value starts with / or relative to the root of the implemented role or playbook. This argument is mutually exclusive with the I(lines) and I(parents) arguments. It can be a Jinja2 template as well.

save_when: not required, default: never. # When changes are made to the device running-configuration, the changes are not copied to non-volatile storage by default.  Using this argument will change that before.  If the argument is set to I(always), then the running-config will always be copied to the startup-config and the I(modified) flag will always be set to True.  If the argument is set to I(modified), then the running-config will only be copied to the startup-config if it has changed since the last save to startup-config.  If the argument is set to I(never), the running-config will never be copied to the startup-config

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

intended_config: not required, default: undefined. # The C(intended_config) provides the master configuration that the node should conform to and is used to check the final running-config against.   This argument will not modify any settings on the remote device and is strictly used to check the compliance of the current device's configuration against.  When specifying this argument, the task should also modify the C(diff_against) value and set it to I(intended).

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

defaults: not required, default: false. # The I(defaults) argument will influence how the running-config is collected from the device.  When the value is set to true, the command used to collect the running-config is append with the all keyword.  When the value is set to false, the command is issued without the all keyword
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

save: not required, default: false. # The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running-config to startup-config.  This operation is performed after any changes are made to the current running config.  If no changes are made, the configuration is still saved to the startup config.  This option will always cause the module to return changed.,This option is deprecated as of Ansible 2.4, use C(save_when)

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

eos_eapi.description: Manage and configure Arista EOS eAPI.
body: eos_eapi

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

local_http_port: not required, default: 8080. # Configures the HTTP port that will listen for connections when the HTTP transport protocol is enabled.  This argument accepts integer values in the valid range of 1 to 65535.

http_port: not required, default: 80. # Configures the HTTP port that will listen for connections when the HTTP transport protocol is enabled.  This argument accepts integer values in the valid range of 1 to 65535.

http: not required, default: false. # The C(http) argument controls the operating state of the HTTP transport protocol when eAPI is present in the running-config. When the value is set to True, the HTTP protocol is enabled and when the value is set to False, the HTTP protocol is disabled. By default, when eAPI is first configured, the HTTP protocol is disabled.

https_port: not required, default: 443. # Configures the HTTP port that will listen for connections when the HTTP transport protocol is enabled.  This argument accepts integer values in the valid range of 1 to 65535.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

state: not required, default: started. # The C(state) argument controls the operational state of eAPI on the remote device.  When this argument is set to C(started), eAPI is enabled to receive requests and when this argument is C(stopped), eAPI is disabled and will not receive requests.

vrf: not required, default: default. # The C(vrf) argument will configure eAPI to listen for connections in the specified VRF.  By default, eAPI transports will listen for connections in the global table.  This value requires the VRF to already be created otherwise the task will fail.

https: not required, default: true. # The C(https) argument controls the operating state of the HTTPS transport protocol when eAPI is present in the running-config. When the value is set to True, the HTTPS protocol is enabled and when the value is set to False, the HTTPS protocol is disabled. By default, when eAPI is first configured, the HTTPS protocol is enabled.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

config: not required, default: nul. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for comparison.

local_http: not required, default: false. # The C(local_http) argument controls the operating state of the local HTTP transport protocol when eAPI is present in the running-config.  When the value is set to True, the HTTP protocol is enabled and restricted to connections from localhost only.  When the value is set to False, the HTTP local protocol is disabled.,Note is value is independent of the C(http) argument

socket: not required, default: false. # The C(socket) argument controls the operating state of the UNIX Domain Socket used to receive eAPI requests.  When the value of this argument is set to True, the UDS will listen for eAPI requests.  When the value is set to False, the UDS will not be available to handle requests.  By default when eAPI is first configured, the UDS is disabled.

eos_facts.description: Collect facts from remote devices running Arista EOS
body: eos_facts

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

gather_subset: not required, default: !config. # When supplied, this argument will restrict the facts collected to a given subset.  Possible values for this argument include all, hardware, config, and interfaces.  Can specify a list of values to include a larger subset.  Values can also be used with an initial C(M(!)) to specify that a specific subset should not be collected.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.
eos_logging
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of logging definitions.
state: not required, default: present. # State of the logging configuration.
name: not required, default: undefined. # If value of C(dest) is I(host) C(name) should be specified, which indicates hostname or IP address.
level: not required, default: undefined. # Set logging severity levels.
dest: not required, default: undefined. # Destination of the logs.
facility: not required, default: undefined. # Set logging facility.
size: not required, default: undefined. # Size of buffer. The acceptable value is in range from 10 to 2147483647 bytes.

eos_system.description: Manage the system attributes on Arista EOS devices
body: eos_system

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
hostname: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the device hostname parameter. This option takes an ASCII string value.

lookup_source: not required, default: undefined. # Provides one or more source interfaces to use for performing DNS lookups.  The interface provided in C(lookup_source) can only exist in a single VRF.  This argument accepts either a list of interface names or a list of hashes that configure the interface name and VRF name.  See examples.

domain_search: not required, default: undefined. # Provides the list of domain suffixes to append to the hostname for the purpose of doing name resolution. This argument accepts a list of names and will be reconciled with the current active configuration on the running node.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

domain_name: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the IP domain name on the remote device to the provided value. Value should be in the dotted name form and will be appended to the C(hostname) to create a fully-qualified domain name.

state: not required, default: present. # State of the configuration values in the device's current active configuration.  When set to I(present), the values should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the values should not be in the device active configuration
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

name_servers: not required, default: undefined. # List of DNS name servers by IP address to use to perform name resolution lookups.  This argument accepts either a list of DNS servers or a list of hashes that configure the name server and VRF name.  See examples.

eos_user.description: Manage the collection of local users on EOS devices
body: eos_user

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

update_password: not required, default: always. # Since passwords are encrypted in the device running config, this argument will instruct the module when to change the password.  When set to C(always), the password will always be updated in the device and when set to C(on_create) the password will be updated only if the username is created.

configured_password: not required, default: undefined. # The password to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device. The password needs to be provided in clear and it will be encrypted on the device. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider password).

name: not required, default: undefined. # The username to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device.  This argument accepts a stringv value and is mutually exclusive with the C(aggregate) argument. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider username).

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
nopassword: not required, default: undefined. # Defines the username without assigning a password.  This will allow the user to login to the system without being authenticated by a password.

purge: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to consider the resource definition absolute.  It will remove any previously configured usernames on the device with the exception of the `admin` user which cannot be deleted per EOS constraints.

privilege: not required, default: undefined. # The C(privilege) argument configures the privilege level of the user when logged into the system.  This argument accepts integer values in the range of 1 to 15.

state: not required, default: present. # Configures the state of the username definition as it relates to the device operational configuration.  When set to I(present), the username(s) should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the username(s) should not be in the device active configuration

role: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the role for the username in the device running configuration.  The argument accepts a string value defining the role name.  This argument does not check if the role has been configured on the device.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # The set of username objects to be configured on the remote Arista EOS device.  The list entries can either be the username or a hash of username and properties.  This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(username) argument. alias C(users).
sshkey: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the SSH public key to configure for the given username.  This argument accepts a valid SSH key value.

eos_vlan.description: Manage VLANs on Arista EOS network devices
body: eos_vlan
purge: not required, default: false. # Purge VLANs not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
delay: not required, default: 10. # Delay the play should wait to check for declarative intent params values.

aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of VLANs definitions.

eos_vrf.description: Manage VRFs on Arista EOS network devices
body: eos_vrf
delay: not required, default: 10. # Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device. This wait is applicable for operational state arguments.
rd: not required, default: undefined. # Route distinguisher of the VRF
state: not required, default: present. # State of the VRF configuration.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the VRF.
purge: not required, default: false. # Purge VRFs not defined in the I(aggregate) parameter.
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of VRFs definitions
interfaces: not required, default: undefined. # List of interfaces to check the VRF has been configured correctly.
execute_lambda
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

name: not required, default: None. # The name of the function to be invoked. This can only be used for invocations within the calling account. To invoke a function in another account, use I(function_arn) to specify the full ARN.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

dry_run: not required, default: false. # Do not *actually* invoke the function. A C(DryRun) call will check that the caller has permissions to call the function, especially for checking cross-account permissions.
function_arn: not required, default: None. # The name of the function to be invoked

tail_log: not required, default: false. # If C(tail_log=true), the result of the task will include the last 4 KB of the CloudWatch log for the function execution. Log tailing only works if you use synchronous invocation C(wait=true). This is usually used for development or testing Lambdas.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.

version_qualifier: not required, default: LATEST. # Which version/alias of the function to run. This defaults to the C(LATEST) revision, but can be set to any existing version or alias. See https;//docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/versioning-aliases.html for details.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.
payload: not required, default: [object Object]. # A dictionary in any form to be provided as input to the Lambda function.

wait: not required, default: true. # Whether to wait for the function results or not. If I(wait) is false, the task will not return any results. To wait for the Lambda function to complete, set C(wait=true) and the result will be available in the I(output) key.

exo_dns_domain.description: Manages domain records on Exoscale DNS API.
body: exo_dns_domain
state: not required, default: present. # State of the resource.
api_timeout: not required, default: 10. # HTTP timeout to Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_TIMEOUT) is used as default, when defined.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the record.
api_secret: not required, default: undefined. # Secret key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_SECRET) is used as default, when defined.
api_key: not required, default: undefined. # API key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_KEY) is used as default, when defined.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # Validate SSL certs of the Exoscale DNS API.
api_region: not required, default: cloudstack. # Name of the ini section in the C(cloustack.ini) file.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_REGION) is used as default, when defined.

exo_dns_record.description: Manages DNS records on Exoscale DNS.
body: exo_dns_record
domain: required, default: undefined. # Domain the record is related to.

multiple: not required, default: undefined. # Whether there are more than one records with similar C(name).,Only allowed with C(record_type=A).,C(content) will not be updated as it is used as key to find the record.
name: not required, default: . # Name of the record.
prio: not required, default: undefined. # Priority of the record.
api_secret: not required, default: undefined. # Secret key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_SECRET) is used as default, when defined.
api_timeout: not required, default: 10. # HTTP timeout to Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_TIMEOUT) is used as default, when defined.
api_region: not required, default: cloudstack. # Name of the ini section in the C(cloustack.ini) file.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_REGION) is used as default, when defined.
content: not required, default: undefined. # Content of the record.,Required if C(state=present) or C(name="")
record_type: not required, default: A. # Type of the record.
state: not required, default: present. # State of the record.
ttl: not required, default: 3600. # TTL of the record in seconds.
api_key: not required, default: undefined. # API key of the Exoscale DNS API.,Since 2.4, the ENV variable C(CLOUDSTACK_KEY) is used as default, when defined.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # Validate SSL certs of the Exoscale DNS API.

expect.description: Executes a command and responds to prompts.
body: expect
creates: not required, default: undefined. # A filename, when it already exists, this step will B(not) be run.
chdir: not required, default: undefined. # Change into this directory before running the command.
command: required, default: undefined. # The command module takes command to run.

responses: required, default: undefined. # Mapping of expected string/regex and string to respond with. If the response is a list, successive matches return successive responses. List functionality is new in 2.1.
timeout: not required, default: 30. # Amount of time in seconds to wait for the expected strings.
removes: not required, default: undefined. # A filename, when it does not exist, this step will B(not) be run.
echo: not required, default: false. # Whether or not to echo out your response strings.

facter.description: Runs the discovery program I(facter) on the remote system
body: facter
fail
msg: not required, default: 'Failed as requested from task'. # The customized message used for failing execution. If omitted, fail will simply bail out with a generic message.

fetch.description: Fetches a file from remote nodes
body: fetch

dest: required, default: null. # A directory to save the file into. For example, if the I(dest) directory is C(/backup) a I(src) file named C(/etc/profile) on host C(host.example.com), would be saved into C(/backup/host.example.com/etc/profile)
src: required, default: null. # The file on the remote system to fetch. This I(must) be a file, not a directory. Recursive fetching may be supported in a later release.
validate_checksum: not required, default: yes. # Verify that the source and destination checksums match after the files are fetched.

fail_on_missing: not required, default: yes. # When set to 'yes', the task will fail if the remote file cannot be read for any reason.  Prior to Ansible-2.4, setting this would only fail if the source file was missing.,The default was changed to "yes" in Ansible-2.4.

flat: not required, default: undefined. # Allows you to override the default behavior of appending hostname/path/to/file to the destination.  If dest ends with '/', it will use the basename of the source file, similar to the copy module. Obviously this is only handy if the filenames are unique.
file
src: not required, default: null. # path of the file to link to (applies only to C(state=link)). Will accept absolute, relative and nonexisting paths. Relative paths are not expanded.

force: not required, default: no. # force the creation of the symlinks in two cases: the source file does not exist (but will appear later); the destination exists and is a file (so, we need to unlink the "path" file and create symlink to the "src" file in place of it).
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

state: not required, default: file. # If C(directory), all immediate subdirectories will be created if they do not exist, since 1.7 they will be created with the supplied permissions. If C(file), the file will NOT be created if it does not exist, see the M(copy) or M(template) module if you want that behavior.  If C(link), the symbolic link will be created or changed. Use C(hard) for hardlinks. If C(absent), directories will be recursively deleted, and files or symlinks will be unlinked. Note that C(absent) will not cause C(file) to fail if the C(path) does not exist as the state did not change. If C(touch) (new in 1.4), an empty file will be created if the C(path) does not exist, while an existing file or directory will receive updated file access and modification times (similar to the way `touch` works from the command line).

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
recurse: not required, default: no. # recursively set the specified file attributes (applies only to state=directory)
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
follow: not required, default: no. # This flag indicates that filesystem links, if they exist, should be followed.

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
path: required, default: . # path to the file being managed.  Aliases: I(dest), I(name)
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).

filesystem.description: Makes file system on block device
body: filesystem
resizefs: not required, default: no. # If yes, if the block device and filessytem size differ, grow the filesystem into the space. Note, XFS Will only grow if mounted.
force: not required, default: no. # If yes, allows to create new filesystem on devices that already has filesystem.
dev: required, default: undefined. # Target block device.
opts: not required, default: undefined. # List of options to be passed to mkfs command.
fstype: required, default: undefined. # File System type to be created.,reiserfs support was added in 2.2.

find.description: Return a list of files based on specific criteria
body: find
paths: required, default: undefined. # List of paths of directories to search. All paths must be fully qualified.
file_type: not required, default: file. # Type of file to select.,The 'link' and 'any' choices were added in version 2.3.

age: not required, default: undefined. # Select files whose age is equal to or greater than the specified time. Use a negative age to find files equal to or less than the specified time. You can choose seconds, minutes, hours, days, or weeks by specifying the first letter of any of those words (e.g., "1w").
contains: not required, default: undefined. # One or more regex patterns which should be matched against the file content.
recurse: not required, default: no. # If target is a directory, recursively descend into the directory looking for files.
age_stamp: not required, default: mtime. # Choose the file property against which we compare age.

patterns: not required, default: *. # One or more (shell or regex) patterns, which type is controlled by C(use_regex) option.,The patterns restrict the list of files to be returned to those whose basenames match at least one of the patterns specified. Multiple patterns can be specified using a list.
get_checksum: not required, default: no. # Set this to true to retrieve a file's sha1 checksum.
use_regex: not required, default: no. # If false the patterns are file globs (shell) if true they are python regexes.
follow: not required, default: no. # Set this to true to follow symlinks in path for systems with python 2.6+.
hidden: not required, default: no. # Set this to true to include hidden files, otherwise they'll be ignored.

size: not required, default: undefined. # Select files whose size is equal to or greater than the specified size. Use a negative size to find files equal to or less than the specified size. Unqualified values are in bytes, but b, k, m, g, and t can be appended to specify bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, gigabytes, and terabytes, respectively. Size is not evaluated for directories.
firewalld

zone: not required, default: system-default(public). # The firewalld zone to add/remove to/from (NOTE: default zone can be configured per system but "public" is default from upstream. Available choices can be extended based on per-system configs, listed here are "out of the box" defaults).
service: not required, default: null. # Name of a service to add/remove to/from firewalld - service must be listed in output of firewall-cmd --get-services.
masquerade: not required, default: null. # The masquerade setting you would like to enable/disable to/from zones within firewalld
immediate: not required, default: false. # Should this configuration be applied immediately, if set as permanent
source: not required, default: null. # The source/network you would like to add/remove to/from firewalld
state: required, default: undefined. # Should this port accept(enabled) or reject(disabled) connections.

permanent: not required, default: null. # Should this configuration be in the running firewalld configuration or persist across reboots. As of Ansible version 2.3, permanent operations can operate on firewalld configs when it's not running (requires firewalld >= 3.0.9). (NOTE: If this is false, immediate is assumed true.)
timeout: not required, default: 0. # The amount of time the rule should be in effect for when non-permanent.
interface: not required, default: null. # The interface you would like to add/remove to/from a zone in firewalld
port: not required, default: null. # Name of a port or port range to add/remove to/from firewalld. Must be in the form PORT/PROTOCOL or PORT-PORT/PROTOCOL for port ranges.
rich_rule: not required, default: null. # Rich rule to add/remove to/from firewalld.

flowadm.description: Manage bandwidth resource control and priority for protocols, services and zones on Solaris/illumos systems
body: flowadm

dsfield: not required, default: undefined. # - Identifies the 8-bit differentiated services field (as defined in RFC 2474). The optional dsfield_mask is used to state the bits of interest in the differentiated services field when comparing with the dsfield value. Both values must be in hexadecimal.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the configured flow is temporary. Temporary flows do not persist across reboots.
name: required, default: undefined. # - A flow is defined as a set of attributes based on Layer 3 and Layer 4 headers, which can be used to identify a protocol, service, or a zone.

maxbw: not required, default: undefined. # - Sets the full duplex bandwidth for the flow. The bandwidth is specified as an integer with one of the scale suffixes(K, M, or G for Kbps, Mbps, and Gbps). If no units are specified, the input value will be read as Mbps.
local_port: not required, default: undefined. # Identifies a service specified by the local port.
local_ip: not required, default: undefined. # Identifies a network flow by the local IP address.
remove_ip: not required, default: undefined. # Identifies a network flow by the remote IP address.
priority: not required, default: medium. # Sets the relative priority for the flow.
state: not required, default: present. # Create/delete/enable/disable an IP address on the network interface.
link: not required, default: undefined. # Specifiies a link to configure flow on.
transport: not required, default: undefined. # - Specifies a Layer 4 protocol to be used. It is typically used in combination with I(local_port) to identify the service that needs special attention.

flowdock.description: Send a message to a flowdock
body: flowdock
from_name: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only) Name of the message sender
from_address: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only - required) Email address of the message sender
tags: not required, default: undefined. # tags of the message, separated by commas
type: required, default: undefined. # Whether to post to 'inbox' or 'chat'
external_user_name: not required, default: undefined. # (chat only - required) Name of the "user" sending the message
project: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only) Human readable identifier for more detailed message categorization
source: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only - required) Human readable identifier of the application that uses the Flowdock API
token: required, default: undefined. # API token.
link: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only) Link associated with the message. This will be used to link the message subject in Team Inbox.
reply_to: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only) Email address for replies
subject: not required, default: undefined. # (inbox only - required) Subject line of the message
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
msg: required, default: undefined. # Content of the message
foreman
username: required, default: undefined. # Username on Foreman server
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for user accessing Foreman server
params: required, default: undefined. # Parameters associated to the entity resource to set or edit in dictionary format (e.g. name, description)
server_url: required, default: undefined. # URL of Foreman server
entity: required, default: undefined. # The Foreman resource that the action will be performed on (e.g. organization, host)
fortios_address
username: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
comment: not required, default: undefined. # free text to describe address.
config_file: not required, default: undefined. # Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
file_mode: not required, default: false. # Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
backup_path: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
country: not required, default: undefined. # 2 letter country code (like FR).
state: required, default: undefined. # Specifies if address need to be added or deleted.

value: not required, default: undefined. # Address value, based on type. If type=fqdn, somthing like www.google.com. If type=ipmask, you can use simple ip (192.168.0.1), ip+mask (192.168.0.1 255.255.255.0) or CIDR (192.168.0.1/32).
interface: not required, default: any. # interface name the address apply to.
host: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
end_ip: not required, default: undefined. # Last ip in range (used only with type=iprange).
backup_filename: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS
timeout: not required, default: 60. # Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.
type: not required, default: undefined. # Type of the address.
start_ip: not required, default: undefined. # First ip in range (used only with type=iprange).
password: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
vdom: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the address to add or delete.

fortios_config.description: Manage config on Fortinet FortiOS firewall devices
body: fortios_config
username: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
src: not required, default: undefined. # The I(src) argument provides a path to the configuration template to load into the remote device.
config_file: not required, default: undefined. # Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
file_mode: not required, default: false. # Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
backup_path: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
filter: not required, default: . # Only for partial backup, you can restrict by giving expected configuration path (ex. firewall address).
host: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
backup_filename: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS
timeout: not required, default: 60. # Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
vdom: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration

fortios_ipv4_policy.description: Manage IPv4 policy objects on Fortinet FortiOS firewall devices
body: fortios_ipv4_policy
comment: not required, default: undefined. # free text to describe policy.
application_list: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies Application Control name.
service_negate: not required, default: false. # Negate policy service(s) defined in service value.
ips_sensor: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies IPS Sensor profile name.
backup_filename: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the backup filename. If omitted filename will be formatted like HOST_config.YYYY-MM-DD@HH:MM:SS

id: required, default: undefined. # Policy ID. Warning: policy ID number is different than Policy sequence number. The policy ID is the number assigned at policy creation. The sequence number represents the order in which the Fortigate will evaluate the rule for policy enforcement, and also the order in which rules are listed in the GUI and CLI. These two numbers do not necessarily correlate: this module is based off policy ID. TIP: policy ID can be viewed in the GUI by adding 'ID' to the display columns
fixedport: not required, default: false. # Use fixed port for nat.
src_addr: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies source address (or group) object name(s). Required when I(state=present).
service: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies policy service(s), could be a list (ex: ['MAIL','DNS']). Required when I(state=present).
poolname: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies NAT pool name.
state: not required, default: present. # Specifies if policy I(id) need to be added or deleted.
nat: not required, default: false. # Enable or disable Nat.
src_addr_negate: not required, default: false. # Negate source address param.
username: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the username used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
config_file: not required, default: undefined. # Path to configuration file. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
file_mode: not required, default: false. # Don't connect to any device, only use I(config_file) as input and Output.
schedule: not required, default: always. # defines policy schedule.
src_intf: not required, default: any. # Specifies source interface name.
dst_addr_negate: not required, default: false. # Negate destination address param.
host: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the DNS hostname or IP address for connecting to the remote fortios device. Required when I(file_mode) is False.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the password used to authenticate to the remote device. Required when I(file_mode) is True.
vdom: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies on which vdom to apply configuration
webfilter_profile: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies Webfilter profile name.
logtraffic_start: not required, default: false. # Logs beginning of session as well.
backup_path: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies where to store backup files. Required if I(backup=yes).
policy_action: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies accept or deny action policy. Required when I(state=present).
dst_intf: not required, default: any. # Specifies destination interface name.
av_profile: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies Antivirus profile name.
timeout: not required, default: 60. # Timeout in seconds for connecting to the remote device.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the i(backup) folder.
dst_addr: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies destination address (or group) object name(s). Required when I(state=present).
