gc_storage.description: This module manages objects/buckets in Google Cloud Storage.
body: gc_storage
src: not required, default: null. # The source file path when performing a PUT operation.
force: not required, default: true. # Forces an overwrite either locally on the filesystem or remotely with the object/key. Used with PUT and GET operations.

permission: not required, default: private. # This option let's the user set the canned permissions on the object/bucket that are created. The permissions that can be set are 'private', 'public-read', 'authenticated-read'.
dest: not required, default: undefined. # The destination file path when downloading an object/key with a GET operation.
gs_access_key: required, default: null. # GS access key. If not set then the value of the GS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable is used.
object: not required, default: null. # Keyname of the object inside the bucket. Can be also be used to create "virtual directories" (see examples).
bucket: required, default: undefined. # Bucket name.
mode: required, default: null. # Switches the module behaviour between upload, download, get_url (return download url) , get_str (download object as string), create (bucket) and delete (bucket).
gs_secret_key: required, default: null. # GS secret key. If not set then the value of the GS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

expiration: not required, default: null. # Time limit (in seconds) for the URL generated and returned by GCA when performing a mode=put or mode=get_url operation. This url is only available when public-read is the acl for the object.
region: not required, default: US. # The gs region to use. If not defined then the value 'US' will be used. See U(https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/bucket-locations)
versioning: not required, default: null. # Whether versioning is enabled or disabled (note that once versioning is enabled, it can only be suspended)
headers: not required, default: {}. # Headers to attach to object.

gcdns_record.description: Creates or removes resource records in Google Cloud DNS
body: gcdns_record

zone_id: not required, default: undefined. # The Google Cloud ID of the zone (e.g., example-com).,One of either I(zone) or I(zone_id) must be specified as an option, or the module will fail.,These usually take the form of domain names with the dots replaced with dashes. A zone ID will never have any dots in it.,I(zone_id) can be faster than I(zone) in projects with a large number of zones.,If both I(zone) and I(zone_id) are specified, I(zone_id) will be used.

zone: not required, default: undefined. # The DNS domain name of the zone (e.g., example.com).,One of either I(zone) or I(zone_id) must be specified as an option, or the module will fail.,If both I(zone) and I(zone_id) are specified, I(zone_id) will be used.
record: required, default: undefined. # The fully-qualified domain name of the resource record.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # The e-mail address for a service account with access to Google Cloud DNS.
ttl: not required, default: 300. # The amount of time in seconds that a resource record will remain cached by a caching resolver.

pem_file: not required, default: null. # The path to the PEM file associated with the service account email.,This option is deprecated and may be removed in a future release. Use I(credentials_file) instead.

record_data: not required, default: undefined. # The record_data to use for the resource record.,I(record_data) must be specified if I(state) is C(present) or I(overwrite) is C(True), or the module will fail.,Valid record_data vary based on the record's I(type). In addition, resource records that contain a DNS domain name in the value field (e.g., CNAME, PTR, SRV, .etc) MUST include a trailing dot in the value.,Individual string record_data for TXT records must be enclosed in double quotes.,For resource records that have the same name but different record_data (e.g., multiple A records), they must be defined as multiple list entries in a single record.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the given resource record should or should not be present.
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # The path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.
project_id: not required, default: null. # The Google Cloud Platform project ID to use.
type: required, default: undefined. # The type of resource record to add.

overwrite: not required, default: false. # Whether an attempt to overwrite an existing record should succeed or fail. The behavior of this option depends on I(state).,If I(state) is C(present) and I(overwrite) is C(True), this module will replace an existing resource record of the same name with the provided I(record_data). If I(state) is C(present) and I(overwrite) is C(False), this module will fail if there is an existing resource record with the same name and type, but different resource data.,If I(state) is C(absent) and I(overwrite) is C(True), this module will remove the given resource record unconditionally. If I(state) is C(absent) and I(overwrite) is C(False), this module will fail if the provided record_data do not match exactly with the existing resource record's record_data.

gcdns_zone.description: Creates or removes zones in Google Cloud DNS
body: gcdns_zone
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the given zone should or should not be present.
description: not required, default: . # An arbitrary text string to use for the zone description.

zone: required, default: undefined. # The DNS domain name of the zone.,This is NOT the Google Cloud DNS zone ID (e.g., example-com). If you attempt to specify a zone ID, this module will attempt to create a TLD and will fail.
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # The path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # The e-mail address for a service account with access to Google Cloud DNS.
project_id: not required, default: null. # The Google Cloud Platform project ID to use.

pem_file: not required, default: null. # The path to the PEM file associated with the service account email.,This option is deprecated and may be removed in a future release. Use I(credentials_file) instead.
gce

disks: not required, default: null. # a list of persistent disks to attach to the instance; a string value gives the name of the disk; alternatively, a dictionary value can define 'name' and 'mode' ('READ_ONLY' or 'READ_WRITE'). The first entry will be the boot disk (which must be READ_WRITE).
num_instances: not required, default: undefined. # can be used with 'name', specifies the number of nodes to provision using 'name' as a base name
ip_forward: not required, default: false. # set to true if the instance can forward ip packets (useful for gateways)
image: not required, default: debian-8. # image string to use for the instance (default will follow latest stable debian image)

service_account_permissions: not required, default: null. # service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)
pem_file: not required, default: null. # path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
instance_names: not required, default: null. # a comma-separated list of instance names to create or destroy
machine_type: not required, default: n1-standard-1. # machine type to use for the instance, use 'n1-standard-1' by default
external_projects: not required, default: null. # A list of other projects (accessible with the provisioning credentials) to be searched for the image.
name: not required, default: undefined. # either a name of a single instance or when used with 'num_instances', the base name of a cluster of nodes
disk_size: not required, default: 10. # The size of the boot disk created for this instance (in GB)
network: not required, default: default. # name of the network, 'default' will be used if not specified
zone: required, default: us-central1-a. # the GCE zone to use. The list of available zones is at U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/regions-zones/regions-zones#available).
external_ip: not required, default: ephemeral. # type of external ip, ephemeral by default; alternatively, a fixed gce ip or ip name can be given. Specify 'none' if no external ip is desired.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
tags: not required, default: null. # a comma-separated list of tags to associate with the instance
persistent_boot_disk: not required, default: false. # if set, create the instance with a persistent boot disk
disk_auto_delete: not required, default: true. # if set boot disk will be removed after instance destruction
preemptible: not required, default: false. # if set to true, instances will be preemptible and time-limited. (requires libcloud >= 0.20.0)
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the resource
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
subnetwork: not required, default: null. # name of the subnetwork in which the instance should be created
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
image_family: not required, default: null. # image family from which to select the image.  The most recent non-deprecated image in the family will be used.
metadata: not required, default: null. # a hash/dictionary of custom data for the instance; '{"key":"value", ...}'

gce_eip.description: Create or Destroy Global or Regional External IP addresses.
body: gce_eip
region: required, default: undefined. # Region to create the address in. Set to 'global' to create a global address.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of Address.
state: not required, default: present. # The state the address should be in. C(present) or C(absent) are the only valid options.
gce_img
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
name: required, default: null. # the name of the image to create or delete
family: not required, default: null. # an optional family name
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
pem_file: not required, default: null. # path to the pem file associated with the service account email
source: not required, default: null. # the source disk or the Google Cloud Storage URI to create the image from
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the image
timeout: not required, default: 180. # timeout for the operation
zone: not required, default: us-central1-a. # the zone of the disk specified by source
description: not required, default: null. # an optional description

gce_instance_template.description: create or destroy instance templates of Compute Engine of GCP.
body: gce_instance_template
description: not required, default: null. # description of instance template
name: required, default: null. # The name of the GCE instance template.
tags: not required, default: null. # a comma-separated list of tags to associate with the instance
automatic_restart: not required, default: null. # Defines whether the instance should be automatically restarted when it is terminated by Compute Engine.
image: not required, default: null. # The image to use to create the instance. Cannot specify both both I(image) and I(source).

service_account_permissions: not required, default: null. # service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)
pem_file: not required, default: null. # path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
subnetwork_region: not required, default: null. # Region that subnetwork resides in. (Required for subnetwork to successfully complete)
disk_type: not required, default: pd-standard. # Specify a C(pd-standard) disk or C(pd-ssd) for an SSD disk.
size: not required, default: f1-micro. # The desired machine type for the instance template.
network: not required, default: default. # The network to associate with the instance.

external_ip: not required, default: ephemeral. # The external IP address to use. If C(ephemeral), a new non-static address will be used.  If C(None), then no external address will be used.  To use an existing static IP address specify address name.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email

disks: not required, default: null. # a list of persistent disks to attach to the instance; a string value gives the name of the disk; alternatively, a dictionary value can define 'name' and 'mode' ('READ_ONLY' or 'READ_WRITE'). The first entry will be the boot disk (which must be READ_WRITE).
nic_gce_struct: not required, default: null. # Support passing in the GCE-specific formatted networkInterfaces[] structure.
disk_auto_delete: not required, default: true. # Indicate that the boot disk should be deleted when the Node is deleted.
source: not required, default: null. # A source disk to attach to the instance. Cannot specify both I(image) and I(source).
state: not required, default: present. # The desired state for the instance template.

disks_gce_struct: not required, default: null. # Support passing in the GCE-specific formatted formatted disks[] structure. Case sensitive. see U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instanceTemplates#resource) for detailed information
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
image_family: not required, default: null. # The image family to use to create the instance. If I(image) has been used I(image_family) is ignored. Cannot specify both I(image) and I(source).
subnetwork: not required, default: null. # The Subnetwork resource name for this instance.
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
can_ip_forward: not required, default: false. # Set to True to allow instance to send/receive non-matching src/dst packets.
preemptible: not required, default: null. # Defines whether the instance is preemptible.
metadata: not required, default: null. # a hash/dictionary of custom data for the instance; '{"key":"value", ...}'

gce_labels.description: Create, Update or Destory GCE Labels.
body: gce_labels
labels: not required, default: undefined. # A list of labels (key/value pairs) to add or remove for the resource.
resource_url: not required, default: undefined. # The 'self_link' for the resource (instance, disk, snapshot, etc)
resource_name: not required, default: undefined. # The name of resource.
resource_type: not required, default: undefined. # The type of resource (instances, disks, snapshots, images)
resource_location: not required, default: undefined. # The location of resource (global, us-central1-f, etc.)
gce_lb
httphealthcheck_host: not required, default: null. # host header to pass through on HTTP check requests
protocol: not required, default: tcp. # the protocol used for the load-balancer packet forwarding, tcp or udp
pem_file: not required, default: null. # path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.
members: not required, default: undefined. # a list of zone/nodename pairs, e.g ['us-central1-a/www-a', ...]
httphealthcheck_port: not required, default: 80. # the TCP port to use for HTTP health checking
httphealthcheck_name: not required, default: null. # the name identifier for the HTTP health check
name: not required, default: null. # name of the load-balancer resource
external_ip: not required, default: null. # the external static IPv4 (or auto-assigned) address for the LB
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
region: not required, default: undefined. # the GCE region where the load-balancer is defined
httphealthcheck_unhealthy_count: not required, default: 2. # number of consecutive failed checks before marking a node unhealthy
httphealthcheck_healthy_count: not required, default: 2. # number of consecutive successful checks before marking a node healthy
httphealthcheck_path: not required, default: /. # the url path to use for HTTP health checking
port_range: not required, default: null. # the port (range) to forward, e.g. 80 or 8000-8888 defaults to all ports
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the LB
httphealthcheck_timeout: not required, default: 5. # the timeout in seconds before a request is considered a failed check
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
httphealthcheck_interval: not required, default: 5. # the duration in seconds between each health check request

gce_mig.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Managed Instance Group (MIG).
body: gce_mig
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Managed Instance Group.
zone: required, default: undefined. # The GCE zone to use for this Managed Instance Group.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email

autoscaling: not required, default: null. # A dictionary of configuration for the autoscaler. 'enabled (bool)', 'name (str)' and policy.max_instances (int) are required fields if autoscaling is used. See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/beta/autoscalers) for more information on Autoscaling.
named_ports: not required, default: null. # Define named ports that backend services can forward data to.  Format is a a list of name:port dictionaries.
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the resource

template: not required, default: undefined. # Instance Template to be used in creating the VMs.  See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-templates) to learn more about Instance Templates.  Required for creating MIGs.
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
project_id: not required, default: null. # GCE project ID
size: not required, default: undefined. # Size of Managed Instance Group.  If MIG already exists, it will be resized to the number provided here.  Required for creating MIGs.

gce_net.description: create/destroy GCE networks and firewall rules
body: gce_net
src_tags: not required, default: . # the source instance tags for creating a firewall rule

ipv4_range: not required, default: undefined. # the IPv4 address range in CIDR notation for the network this parameter is not mandatory when you specified existing network in name parameter, but when you create new network, this parameter is mandatory

target_tags: not required, default: . # the target instance tags for creating a firewall rule
allowed: not required, default: null. # the protocol:ports to allow ('tcp:80' or 'tcp:80,443' or 'tcp:80-800;udp:1-25') this parameter is mandatory when creating or updating a firewall rule
fwname: not required, default: null. # name of the firewall rule
name: not required, default: null. # name of the network
src_range: not required, default: . # the source IPv4 address range in CIDR notation
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the network or firewall
subnet_name: not required, default: null. # name of subnet to create

mode: not required, default: legacy. # network mode for Google Cloud "legacy" indicates a network with an IP address range "auto" automatically generates subnetworks in different regions "custom" uses networks to group subnets of user specified IP address ranges https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/networking#network_types
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
subnet_desc: not required, default: null. # description of subnet to create
gce_pd
size_gb: not required, default: 10. # whole integer size of disk (in GB) to create, default is 10 GB

gce_snapshot.description: Create or destroy snapshots for GCE storage volumes
body: gce_snapshot

gce_tag.description: add or remove tag(s) to/from GCE instances
body: gce_tag
zone: not required, default: us-central1-a. # the zone of the disk specified by source
tags: required, default: null. # comma-separated list of tags to add or remove
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
pem_file: not required, default: null. # path to the pem file associated with the service account email
instance_name: not required, default: null. # The name of the GCE instance to add/remove tags.  Required if instance_pattern is not specified.
state: not required, default: present. # desired state of the tags

instance_pattern: not required, default: null. # The pattern of GCE instance names to match for adding/removing tags.  Full-Python regex is supported. See U(https://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html) for details. If instance_name is not specified, this field is required.
project_id: not required, default: null. # your GCE project ID
gconftool2
state: required, default: undefined. # The action to take upon the key/value.
value_type: not required, default: undefined. # The type of value being set. This is ignored if the state is "get".
key: required, default: undefined. # A GConf preference key is an element in the GConf repository that corresponds to an application preference. See man gconftool-2(1)
direct: not required, default: false. # Access the config database directly, bypassing server.  If direct is specified then the config_source must be specified as well. See man gconftool-2(1)

value: not required, default: undefined. # Preference keys typically have simple values such as strings, integers, or lists of strings and integers. This is ignored if the state is "get". See man gconftool-2(1)
config_source: not required, default: undefined. # Specify a configuration source to use rather than the default path. See man gconftool-2(1)

gcp_backend_service.description: Create or Destroy a Backend Service.
body: gcp_backend_service
protocol: not required, default: undefined. # The protocol this Backend Service uses to communicate with backends. Possible values are HTTP, HTTPS, TCP, and SSL. The default is HTTP.
enable_cdn: not required, default: undefined. # If true, enable Cloud CDN for this Backend Service.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # Service account email
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource

backends: required, default: undefined. # List of backends that make up the backend service. A backend is made up of an instance group and optionally several other parameters.  See U(https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/backendServices) for details.
port_name: not required, default: null. # Name of the port on the managed instance group (MIG) that backend services can forward data to. Required for external load balancing.
timeout: not required, default: undefined. # How many seconds to wait for the backend before considering it a failed request. Default is 30 seconds. Valid range is 1-86400.
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the JSON file associated with the service account email.
healthchecks: required, default: undefined. # List of healthchecks. Only one healthcheck is supported.
backend_service_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Backend Service.
project_id: not required, default: null. # GCE project ID.

gcp_forwarding_rule.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Forwarding_Rule.
body: gcp_forwarding_rule
forwarding_rule_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Forwarding_Rule.
port_range: not required, default: undefined. # For global forwarding rules, must be set to 80 or 8080 for TargetHttpProxy, and 443 for TargetHttpsProxy or TargetSslProxy.
state: required, default: undefined. # The state of the Forwarding Rule. 'present' or 'absent'
protocol: not required, default: undefined. # For global forwarding rules, TCP, UDP, ESP, AH, SCTP or ICMP. Default is TCP.

target: not required, default: undefined. # Target resource for forwarding rule. For global proxy, this is a Global TargetProxy resource. Required for external load balancing (including Global load balancing)

address: not required, default: undefined. # IPv4 or named IP address. Must be of the same scope (regional, global). Reserved addresses can (and probably should) be used for global forwarding rules. You may reserve IPs from the console or via the gce_eip module.
region: not required, default: undefined. # The region for this forwarding rule. Currently, only 'global' is supported.

gcp_healthcheck.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Healthcheck.
body: gcp_healthcheck
healthcheck_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Healthcheck.
healthcheck_type: required, default: undefined. # Type of Healthcheck.
check_interval: not required, default: 5. # How often (in seconds) to send a health check.
service_account_email: not required, default: null. # service account email
healthy_threshold: not required, default: 2. # A so-far unhealthy instance will be marked healthy after this many consecutive successes.

service_account_permissions: not required, default: null. # service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)
unhealthy_threshold: not required, default: 2. # A so-far healthy instance will be marked unhealthy after this many consecutive failures.
host_header: required, default: . # The value of the host header in the health check request. If left empty, the public IP on behalf of which this health check is performed will be used.
state: required, default: undefined. # State of the Healthcheck.
timeout: not required, default: 5. # How long (in seconds) to wait for a response before claiming failure. It is invalid for timeout to have a greater value than check_interval.
credentials_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the JSON file associated with the service account email
project_id: not required, default: null. # Your GCP project ID
port: not required, default: undefined. # The TCP port number for the health check request. The default value is 443 for HTTPS and 80 for HTTP.
request_path: not required, default: /. # The request path of the HTTPS health check request.

gcp_target_proxy.description: Create, Update or Destroy a Target_Proxy.
body: gcp_target_proxy
target_proxy_type: required, default: undefined. # Type of Target_Proxy. HTTP, HTTPS or SSL. Only HTTP is currently supported.
target_proxy_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Target_Proxy.
url_map_name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the Url Map.  Required if type is HTTP or HTTPS proxy.

gcp_url_map.description: Create, Update or Destory a Url_Map.
body: gcp_url_map
default_service: required, default: undefined. # Default Backend Service if no host rules match.

host_rules: not required, default: undefined. # The list of HostRules to use against the URL. Contains a list of hosts and an associated path_matcher.,The 'hosts' parameter is a list of host patterns to match. They must be valid hostnames, except * will match any string of ([a-z0-9-.]*). In that case, * must be the first character and must be followed in the pattern by either - or ..,The 'path_matcher' parameter is name of the PathMatcher to use to match the path portion of the URL if the hostRule matches the URL's host portion.
url_map_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Url_Map.

path_matchers: not required, default: undefined. # The list of named PathMatchers to use against the URL. Contains path_rules, which is a list of paths and an associated service. A default_service can also be specified for each path_matcher.,The 'name' parameter to which this path_matcher is referred by the host_rule.,The 'default_service' parameter is the name of the BackendService resource. This will be used if none of the path_rules defined by this path_matcher is matched by the URL's path portion.,The 'path_rules' parameter is a list of dictionaries containing a list of paths and a service to direct traffic to. Each path item must start with / and the only place a * is allowed is at the end following a /. The string fed to the path matcher does not include any text after the first ? or

gcpubsub.description: Create and Delete Topics/Subscriptions, Publish and pull messages on PubSub.
body: gcpubsub

pull: not required, default: undefined. # Subfield of subscription. Not required. If specified, messages will be retrieved from topic via the provided subscription name. max_messages (int; default None; max number of messages to pull), message_ack (bool; default False; acknowledge the message) and return_immediately (bool; default True, don't wait for messages to appear). If the messages are acknowledged, changed is set to True, otherwise, changed is False.
ack_deadline: not required, default: undefined. # Subfield of subscription. Not required. Default deadline for subscriptions to ACK the message before it is resent. See examples.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Subfield of subscription. Required if subscription is specified. See examples.
publish: not required, default: undefined. # List of dictionaries describing messages and attributes to be published.  Dictionary is in message(str):attributes(dict) format. Only message is required.
topic: required, default: undefined. # GCP pubsub topic name.  Only the name, not the full path, is required.

state: not required, default: present. # State of the topic or queue (absent, present). Applies to the most granular resource. Remove the most granular resource.  If subcription is specified we remove it.  If only topic is specified, that is what is removed. Note that a topic can be removed without first removing the subscription.

push_endpoint: not required, default: undefined. # Subfield of subscription.  Not required.  If specified, message will be sent to an endpoint. See U(https://cloud.google.com/pubsub/docs/advanced#push_endpoints) for more information.

subscription: not required, default: undefined. # Dictionary containing a subscripton name associated with a topic (required), along with optional ack_deadline, push_endpoint and pull. For pulling from a subscription, message_ack (bool), max_messages (int) and return_immediate are available as subfields. See subfields name, push_endpoint and ack_deadline for more information.

gcpubsub_facts.description: List Topics/Subscriptions and Messages from Google PubSub.
body: gcpubsub_facts
topic: not required, default: undefined. # GCP pubsub topic name.  Only the name, not the full path, is required.
state: not required, default: undefined. # list is the only valid option.
view: required, default: undefined. # Choices are 'topics' or 'subscriptions'

gcspanner.description: Create and Delete Instances/Databases on Spanner.
body: gcspanner
instance_id: required, default: undefined. # GCP spanner instance name.

state: not required, default: present. # State of the instance or database (absent, present). Applies to the most granular resource. If a database_name is specified we remove it.  If only instance_id is specified, that is what is removed.
instance_display_name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of Instance to display.  If not specified, instance_id will be used instead.
database_name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of database contained on the instance.
configuration: required, default: undefined. # Configuration the instance should use. Examples are us-central1, asia-east1 and europe-west1.
force_instance_delete: not required, default: false. # To delete an instance, this argument must exist and be true (along with state being equal to absent).
node_count: not required, default: undefined. # Number of nodes in the instance.  If not specified while creating an instance, node_count will be set to 1.
gem
include_dependencies: not required, default: yes. # Whether to include dependencies or not.
executable: not required, default: undefined. # Override the path to the gem executable
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the gem to be managed.
repository: not required, default: undefined. # The repository from which the gem will be installed
build_flags: not required, default: undefined. # Allow adding build flags for gem compilation
include_doc: not required, default: no. # Install with or without docs.
user_install: not required, default: yes. # Install gem in user's local gems cache or for all users
pre_release: not required, default: no. # Allow installation of pre-release versions of the gem.
env_shebang: not required, default: no. # Rewrite the shebang line on installed scripts to use /usr/bin/env.
state: not required, default: present. # The desired state of the gem. C(latest) ensures that the latest version is installed.
version: not required, default: undefined. # Version of the gem to be installed/removed.
gem_source: not required, default: undefined. # The path to a local gem used as installation source.

get_url.description: Downloads files from HTTP, HTTPS, or FTP to node
body: get_url

force: not required, default: no. # If C(yes) and C(dest) is not a directory, will download the file every time and replace the file if the contents change. If C(no), the file will only be downloaded if the destination does not exist. Generally should be C(yes) only for small local files.,Prior to 0.6, this module behaved as if C(yes) was the default.
timeout: not required, default: 10. # Timeout in seconds for URL request.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

dest: required, default: undefined. # Absolute path of where to download the file to.,If C(dest) is a directory, either the server provided filename or, if none provided, the base name of the URL on the remote server will be used. If a directory, C(force) has no effect.,If C(dest) is a directory, the file will always be downloaded (regardless of the C(force) option), but replaced only if the contents changed..
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

force_basic_auth: not required, default: no. # httplib2, the library used by the uri module only sends authentication information when a webservice responds to an initial request with a 401 status. Since some basic auth services do not properly send a 401, logins will fail. This option forces the sending of the Basic authentication header upon initial request.

sha256sum: not required, default: . # If a SHA-256 checksum is passed to this parameter, the digest of the destination file will be calculated after it is downloaded to ensure its integrity and verify that the transfer completed successfully. This option is deprecated. Use C(checksum) instead.
others: not required, default: undefined. # all arguments accepted by the M(file) module also work here
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

client_key: not required, default: undefined. # PEM formatted file that contains your private key to be used for SSL client authentication. If C(client_cert) contains both the certificate and key, this option is not required.
url_password: not required, default: undefined. # The password for use in HTTP basic authentication.,If the C(url_username) parameter is not specified, the C(url_password) parameter will not be used.
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
use_proxy: not required, default: yes. # if C(no), it will not use a proxy, even if one is defined in an environment variable on the target hosts.
headers: not required, default: undefined. # Add custom HTTP headers to a request in the format "key:value,key:value".

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.

checksum: not required, default: . # If a checksum is passed to this parameter, the digest of the destination file will be calculated after it is downloaded to ensure its integrity and verify that the transfer completed successfully. Format: <algorithm>:<checksum>, e.g. checksum="sha256:D98291AC[...]B6DC7B97",If you worry about portability, only the sha1 algorithm is available on all platforms and python versions.,The third party hashlib library can be installed for access to additional algorithms.,Additionally, if a checksum is passed to this parameter, and the file exist under the C(dest) location, the I(destination_checksum) would be calculated, and if checksum equals I(destination_checksum), the file download would be skipped (unless C(force) is true).

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
url: required, default: undefined. # HTTP, HTTPS, or FTP URL in the form (http|https|ftp)://[user[:pass]]@host.domain[:port]/path
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
url_username: not required, default: undefined. # The username for use in HTTP basic authentication.,This parameter can be used without C(url_password) for sites that allow empty passwords.

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
backup: not required, default: no. # Create a backup file including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.

client_cert: not required, default: undefined. # PEM formatted certificate chain file to be used for SSL client authentication. This file can also include the key as well, and if the key is included, C(client_key) is not required.

tmp_dest: not required, default: undefined. # Absolute path of where temporary file is downloaded to.,Defaults to C(TMPDIR), C(TEMP) or C(TMP) env variables or a platform specific value.,U(https://docs.python.org/2/library/tempfile.html#tempfile.tempdir)

getent.description: a wrapper to the unix getent utility
body: getent
fail_key: not required, default: true. # If a supplied key is missing this will make the task fail if True
split: not required, default: None. # character used to split the database values into lists/arrays such as ':' or '	', otherwise  it will try to pick one depending on the database
key: not required, default: . # key from which to return values from the specified database, otherwise the full contents are returned.
database: required, default: undefined. # the name of a getent database supported by the target system (passwd, group, hosts, etc).

git.description: Deploy software (or files) from git checkouts
body: git

force: not required, default: no. # If C(yes), any modified files in the working repository will be discarded.  Prior to 0.7, this was always 'yes' and could not be disabled.  Prior to 1.9, the default was `yes`

track_submodules: not required, default: no. # if C(yes), submodules will track the latest commit on their master branch (or other branch specified in .gitmodules).  If C(no), submodules will be kept at the revision specified by the main project. This is equivalent to specifying the --remote flag to git submodule update.
reference: not required, default: null. # Reference repository (see "git clone --reference ...")
dest: required, default: undefined. # The path of where the repository should be checked out. This parameter is required, unless C(clone) is set to C(no).
accept_hostkey: not required, default: no. # if C(yes), ensure that "-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no" is present as an ssh options.
clone: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), do not clone the repository if it does not exist locally
update: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), do not retrieve new revisions from the origin repository

ssh_opts: not required, default: None. # Creates a wrapper script and exports the path as GIT_SSH which git then automatically uses to override ssh arguments. An example value could be "-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no"
repo: required, default: undefined. # git, SSH, or HTTP(S) protocol address of the git repository.
bare: not required, default: no. # if C(yes), repository will be created as a bare repo, otherwise it will be a standard repo with a workspace.

verify_commit: not required, default: no. # if C(yes), when cloning or checking out a C(version) verify the signature of a GPG signed commit. This requires C(git) version>=2.1.0 to be installed. The commit MUST be signed and the public key MUST be present in the GPG keyring.

archive: not required, default: undefined. # Specify archive file path with extension. If specified, creates an archive file of the specified format containing the tree structure for the source tree. Allowed archive formats ["zip", "tar.gz", "tar", "tgz"]
recursive: not required, default: yes. # if C(no), repository will be cloned without the --recursive option, skipping sub-modules.
executable: not required, default: null. # Path to git executable to use. If not supplied, the normal mechanism for resolving binary paths will be used.
remote: not required, default: origin. # Name of the remote.

refspec: not required, default: null. # Add an additional refspec to be fetched. If version is set to a I(SHA-1) not reachable from any branch or tag, this option may be necessary to specify the ref containing the I(SHA-1). Uses the same syntax as the 'git fetch' command. An example value could be "refs/meta/config".
umask: not required, default: null. # The umask to set before doing any checkouts, or any other repository maintenance.

depth: not required, default: null. # Create a shallow clone with a history truncated to the specified number or revisions. The minimum possible value is C(1), otherwise ignored. Needs I(git>=1.9.1) to work correctly.

version: not required, default: HEAD. # What version of the repository to check out.  This can be the the literal string C(HEAD), a branch name, a tag name. It can also be a I(SHA-1) hash, in which case C(refspec) needs to be specified if the given revision is not already available.
key_file: not required, default: None. # Specify an optional private key file to use for the checkout.
git_config
repo: not required, default: null. # Path to a git repository for reading and writing values from a specific repo.

scope: not required, default: null. # Specify which scope to read/set values from. This is required when setting config values. If this is set to local, you must also specify the repo parameter. It defaults to system only when not using I(list_all)=yes.
list_all: not required, default: false. # List all settings (optionally limited to a given I(scope))
name: not required, default: null. # The name of the setting. If no value is supplied, the value will be read from the config if it has been set.
value: not required, default: null. # When specifying the name of a single setting, supply a value to set that setting to the given value.

github_deploy_key.description: Manages deploy keys for GitHub repositories.
body: github_deploy_key
read_only: not required, default: true. # If C(true), the deploy key will only be able to read repository contents. Otherwise, the deploy key will be able to read and write.
username: not required, default: null. # The username to authenticate with.
force: not required, default: false. # If C(true), forcefully adds the deploy key by deleting any existing deploy key with the same public key or title.
name: required, default: null. # The name for the deploy key.
state: not required, default: present. # The state of the deploy key.
repo: required, default: null. # The name of the GitHub repository.
owner: required, default: null. # The name of the individual account or organization that owns the GitHub repository.
token: not required, default: null. # The OAuth2 token or personal access token to authenticate with. Mutually exclusive with I(password).
key: required, default: null. # The SSH public key to add to the repository as a deploy key.
otp: not required, default: null. # The 6 digit One Time Password for 2-Factor Authentication. Required together with I(username) and I(password).
password: not required, default: null. # The password to authenticate with. A personal access token can be used here in place of a password.
github_hooks

repo: required, default: undefined. # This is the API url for the repository you want to manage hooks for. It should be in the form of: https://api.github.com/repos/user:/repo:. Note this is different than the normal repo url.
oauthkey: required, default: undefined. # The oauth key provided by GitHub. It can be found/generated on GitHub under "Edit Your Profile" >> "Developer settings" >> "Personal Access Tokens"
user: required, default: undefined. # Github username.
content_type: not required, default: json. # Content type to use for requests made to the webhook
action: required, default: undefined. # This tells the githooks module what you want it to do.

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates for the target repo will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
hookurl: not required, default: undefined. # When creating a new hook, this is the url that you want GitHub to post to. It is only required when creating a new hook.
github_issue
repo: required, default: none. # Name of repository from which issue needs to be retrieved.
organization: required, default: none. # Name of the GitHub organization in which the repository is hosted.
issue: required, default: none. # Issue number for which information is required.
action: not required, default: get_status. # Get various details about issue depending upon action specified.
github_key
pubkey: not required, default: none. # SSH public key value. Required when C(state=present).
token: required, default: undefined. # GitHub Access Token with permission to list and create public keys.

force: not required, default: yes. # The default is C(yes), which will replace the existing remote key if it's different than C(pubkey). If C(no), the key will only be set if no key with the given C(name) exists.
name: required, default: undefined. # SSH key name
state: not required, default: present. # Whether to remove a key, ensure that it exists, or update its value.
github_release
body: not required, default: undefined. # Description of the release when creating a release
target: not required, default: undefined. # Target of release when creating a release
repo: required, default: null. # Repository name
token: not required, default: null. # GitHub Personal Access Token for authenticating
tag: not required, default: undefined. # Tag name when creating a release. Required when using action is set to C(create_release).
draft: not required, default: false. # Sets if the release is a draft or not. (boolean)
user: required, default: null. # The GitHub account that owns the repository
action: required, default: undefined. # Action to perform
prerelease: not required, default: false. # Sets if the release is a prerelease or not. (boolean)
password: not required, default: null. # The GitHub account password for the user
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of release when creating a release
gitlab_group
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the group you want to create.
login_user: not required, default: null. # Gitlab user name.
login_token: not required, default: null. # Gitlab token for logging in.
server_url: required, default: undefined. # Url of Gitlab server, with protocol (http or https).
state: not required, default: present. # create or delete group.,Possible values are present and absent.
login_password: not required, default: null. # Gitlab password for login_user
path: not required, default: null. # The path of the group you want to create, this will be server_url/group_path,If not supplied, the group_name will be used.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # When using https if SSL certificate needs to be verified.
gitlab_project
merge_requests_enabled: not required, default: true. # If merge requests can be made or not.,Possible values are true and false.
import_url: not required, default: false. # Git repository which will me imported into gitlab.,Gitlab server needs read access to this git repository.
login_user: not required, default: null. # Gitlab user name.
server_url: required, default: undefined. # Url of Gitlab server, with protocol (http or https).
login_password: not required, default: null. # Gitlab password for login_user

group: not required, default: null. # The name of the group of which this projects belongs to.,When not provided, project will belong to user which is configured in 'login_user' or 'login_token',When provided with username, project will be created for this user. 'login_user' or 'login_token' needs admin rights.
wiki_enabled: not required, default: true. # If an wiki for this project should be available or not.,Possible values are true and false.

visibility_level: not required, default: 0. # Private. visibility_level is 0. Project access must be granted explicitly for each user.,Internal. visibility_level is 10. The project can be cloned by any logged in user.,Public. visibility_level is 20. The project can be cloned without any authentication.,Possible values are 0, 10 and 20.
description: not required, default: null. # An description for the project.
snippets_enabled: not required, default: true. # If creating snippets should be available or not.,Possible values are true and false.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the project
login_token: not required, default: null. # Gitlab token for logging in.
state: not required, default: present. # create or delete project.,Possible values are present and absent.
issues_enabled: not required, default: true. # Whether you want to create issues or not.,Possible values are true and false.
path: not required, default: null. # The path of the project you want to create, this will be server_url/<group>/path,If not supplied, name will be used.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # When using https if SSL certificate needs to be verified.
public: not required, default: false. # If the project is public available or not.,Setting this to true is same as setting visibility_level to 20.,Possible values are true and false.
gitlab_user
username: required, default: undefined. # The username of the user.
group: not required, default: null. # Add user as an member to this group.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the user you want to create
sshkey_file: not required, default: null. # The ssh key itself.
sshkey_name: not required, default: null. # The name of the sshkey
login_user: not required, default: null. # Gitlab user name.
login_token: not required, default: null. # Gitlab token for logging in.
confirm: not required, default: true. # Require confirmation.
server_url: required, default: undefined. # Url of Gitlab server, with protocol (http or https).
access_level: not required, default: null. # The access level to the group. One of the following can be used.,guest,reporter,developer,master,owner
state: not required, default: present. # create or delete group.,Possible values are present and absent.
login_password: not required, default: null. # Gitlab password for login_user
password: required, default: undefined. # The password of the user.
validate_certs: not required, default: true. # When using https if SSL certificate needs to be verified.
email: required, default: undefined. # The email that belongs to the user.
gluster_volume
force: not required, default: undefined. # If brick is being created in the root partition, module will fail. Set force to true to override this behaviour.
replicas: not required, default: undefined. # Replica count for volume
bricks: not required, default: undefined. # Brick paths on servers. Multiple brick paths can be separated by commas.
quota: not required, default: undefined. # Quota value for limit-usage (be sure to use 10.0MB instead of 10MB, see quota list)
stripes: not required, default: undefined. # Stripe count for volume
cluster: not required, default: undefined. # List of hosts to use for probing and brick setup
host: not required, default: undefined. # Override local hostname (for peer probing purposes)
arbiter: not required, default: undefined. # Arbiter count for volume
redundancies: not required, default: undefined. # Redundancy count for volume
transport: not required, default: tcp. # Transport type for volume
name: required, default: undefined. # The volume name
disperses: not required, default: undefined. # Disperse count for volume
state: required, default: undefined. # Use present/absent ensure if a volume exists or not. Use started/stopped to control its availability.
directory: not required, default: undefined. # Directory for limit-usage
start_on_create: not required, default: yes. # Controls whether the volume is started after creation or not
rebalance: not required, default: no. # Controls whether the cluster is rebalanced after changes
options: not required, default: undefined. # A dictionary/hash with options/settings for the volume
group
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the group should be present or not on the remote host.
gid: not required, default: undefined. # Optional I(GID) to set for the group.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the group to manage.
system: not required, default: no. # If I(yes), indicates that the group created is a system group.

group_by.description: Create Ansible groups based on facts
body: group_by
parents: not required, default: all. # The list of the parent groups
key: required, default: undefined. # The variables whose values will be used as groups

grove.description: Sends a notification to a grove.io channel
body: grove
service: not required, default: ansible. # Name of the service (displayed as the "user" in the message)
url: not required, default: undefined. # Service URL for the web client
icon_url: not required, default: undefined. # Icon for the service
message: required, default: undefined. # Message content
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
channel_token: required, default: undefined. # Token of the channel to post to.
gunicorn
venv: not required, default: undefined. # Path to the virtualenv directory.
user: not required, default: undefined. # Switch worker processes to run as this user.
config: not required, default: undefined. # Path to the gunicorn configuration file.
worker: not required, default: undefined. # The type of workers to use. The default class (sync) should handle most "normal" types of workloads.
app: required, default: undefined. # The app module. A name refers to a WSGI callable that should be found in the specified module.
chdir: not required, default: undefined. # Chdir to specified directory before apps loading.
pid: not required, default: undefined. # A filename to use for the PID file. If not set and not found on the configuration file a tmp pid file will be created to check a successful run of gunicorn.
hall
msg: required, default: undefined. # The message you wish to deliver as a notification
room_token: required, default: undefined. # Room token provided to you by setting up the Ansible room integation on U(https://hall.com)
title: required, default: undefined. # The title of the message

picture: not required, default: undefined. # The full URL to the image you wish to use for the Icon of the message. Defaults to U(http://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/330046/file-769078210-png/Official_Logos/ansible_logo_black_square_small.png?t=1421076128627)

haproxy.description: Enable, disable, and set weights for HAProxy backend servers using socket commands.
body: haproxy

drain: not required, default: false. # Wait until the server has no active connections or until the timeout determined by wait_interval and wait_retries is reached.  Continue only after the status changes to 'MAINT'.  This overrides the shutdown_sessions option.
socket: not required, default: /var/run/haproxy.sock. # Path to the HAProxy socket file.

weight: not required, default: null. # The value passed in argument. If the value ends with the `%` sign, then the new weight will be relative to the initially configured weight. Relative weights are only permitted between 0 and 100% and absolute weights are permitted between 0 and 256.
wait_interval: not required, default: 5. # Number of seconds to wait between retries.

state: required, default: null. # Desired state of the provided backend host.,Note that C(drain) state was added in version 2.4. It is supported only by HAProxy version 1.5 or later, if used on versions < 1.5, it will be ignored.
backend: not required, default: auto-detected. # Name of the HAProxy backend pool.
wait_retries: not required, default: 25. # Number of times to check for status after changing the state.
host: required, default: null. # Name of the backend host to change.
fail_on_not_found: not required, default: false. # Fail whenever trying to enable/disable a backend host that does not exist

shutdown_sessions: not required, default: false. # When disabling a server, immediately terminate all the sessions attached to the specified server. This can be used to terminate long-running sessions after a server is put into maintenance mode. Overridden by the drain option.
wait: not required, default: false. # Wait until the server reports a status of 'UP' when `state=enabled`, status of 'MAINT' when `state=disabled` or status of 'DRAIN' when `state=drain`

helm.description: Manages Kubernetes packages with the Helm package manager
body: helm
disable_hooks: not required, default: false. # Whether to disable hooks during the uninstall process
name: not required, default: null. # Release name to manage
namespace: not required, default: default. # Kubernetes namespace where the chart should be installed

chart: not required, default: [object Object]. # A map describing the chart to install. For example:
chart:
  name: memcached
  version: 0.4.0
  source:
    type: repo
    location: https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com
state: not required, default: installed. # Whether to install C(present), remove C(absent), or purge C(purged) a package.
values: not required, default: [object Object]. # A map of value options for the chart.
host: not required, default: localhost. # Tiller's server host
port: not required, default: 44134. # Tiller's server port
hg
repo: required, default: null. # The repository address.
executable: not required, default: null. # Path to hg executable to use. If not supplied, the normal mechanism for resolving binary paths will be used.
force: not required, default: no. # Discards uncommitted changes. Runs C(hg update -C).  Prior to 1.9, the default was `yes`.
dest: required, default: null. # Absolute path of where the repository should be cloned to. This parameter is required, unless clone and update are set to no
clone: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), do not clone the repository if it does not exist locally.
update: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), do not retrieve new revisions from the origin repository
purge: not required, default: no. # Deletes untracked files. Runs C(hg purge).
revision: not required, default: null. # Equivalent C(-r) option in hg command which could be the changeset, revision number, branch name or even tag.
hipchat
from: not required, default: Ansible. # Name the message will appear to be sent from. Max length is 15 characters - above this it will be truncated.
room: required, default: undefined. # ID or name of the room.
color: not required, default: yellow. # Background color for the message.
msg_format: not required, default: text. # Message format.
token: required, default: undefined. # API token.
api: not required, default: https://api.hipchat.com/v1. # API url if using a self-hosted hipchat server. For Hipchat API version 2 use the default URI with C(/v2) instead of C(/v1).
notify: not required, default: yes. # If true, a notification will be triggered for users in the room.
msg: required, default: null. # The message body.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
homebrew
install_options: not required, default: null. # options flags to install a package
state: not required, default: present. # state of the package
name: not required, default: None. # name of package to install/remove
update_homebrew: not required, default: false. # update homebrew itself first

path: not required, default: /usr/local/bin. # ':' separated list of paths to search for 'brew' executable. Since A package (I(formula) in homebrew parlance) location is prefixed relative to the actual path of I(brew) command, providing an alternative I(brew) path enables managing different set of packages in an alternative location in the system.
upgrade_all: not required, default: false. # upgrade all homebrew packages
homebrew_cask
update_homebrew: not required, default: false. # update homebrew itself first. Note that C(brew cask update) is a synonym for C(brew update).
path: not required, default: /usr/local/bin. # ':' separated list of paths to search for 'brew' executable.
state: not required, default: present. # state of the cask
name: required, default: undefined. # name of cask to install/remove
install_options: not required, default: null. # options flags to install a package
homebrew_tap

url: not required, default: undefined. # The optional git URL of the repository to tap. The URL is not assumed to be on GitHub, and the protocol doesn't have to be HTTP. Any location and protocol that git can handle is fine.,I(name) option may not be a list of multiple taps (but a single tap instead) when this option is provided.
state: not required, default: present. # state of the repository.
name: required, default: undefined. # The GitHub user/organization repository to tap.
honeybadger_deployment
repo: not required, default: None. # URL of the project repository
environment: required, default: undefined. # The environment name, typically 'production', 'staging', etc.
token: required, default: undefined. # API token.
user: not required, default: None. # The username of the person doing the deployment
url: not required, default: https://api.honeybadger.io/v1/deploys. # Optional URL to submit the notification to.

validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates for the target url will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
revision: not required, default: None. # A hash, number, tag, or other identifier showing what revision was deployed
hostname
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the host

hpilo_boot.description: Boot system using specific media through HP iLO interface
body: hpilo_boot

force: not required, default: false. # Whether to force a reboot (even when the system is already booted).,As a safeguard, without force, hpilo_boot will refuse to reboot a server that is already running.
media: not required, default: network. # The boot media to boot the system from

image: not required, default: undefined. # The URL of a cdrom, floppy or usb boot media image. protocol://username:password@hostname:port/filename,protocol is either 'http' or 'https',username:password is optional,port is optional
ssl_version: not required, default: TLSv1. # Change the ssl_version used.
host: required, default: undefined. # The HP iLO hostname/address that is linked to the physical system.

state: not required, default: boot_once. # The state of the boot media.,no_boot: Do not boot from the device,boot_once: Boot from the device once and then notthereafter,boot_always: Boot from the device each time the serveris rebooted,connect: Connect the virtual media device and set to boot_always,disconnect: Disconnects the virtual media device and set to no_boot,poweroff: Power off the server
login: not required, default: Administrator. # The login name to authenticate to the HP iLO interface.
password: not required, default: admin. # The password to authenticate to the HP iLO interface.

host: required, default: undefined. # The HP iLO hostname/address that is linked to the physical system.
password: not required, default: admin. # The password to authenticate to the HP iLO interface.
ssl_version: not required, default: TLSv1. # Change the ssl_version used.

hponcfg.description: Configure HP iLO interface using hponcfg
body: hponcfg
path: required, default: undefined. # The XML file as accepted by hponcfg.
executable: not required, default: hponcfg. # Path to the hponcfg executable (`hponcfg` which uses $PATH).

htpasswd.description: manage user files for basic authentication
body: htpasswd
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the user entry should be present or not
name: required, default: undefined. # User name to add or remove
path: required, default: undefined. # Path to the file that contains the usernames and passwords
create: not required, default: yes. # Used with C(state=present). If specified, the file will be created if it does not already exist. If set to "no", will fail if the file does not exist
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password associated with user.,Must be specified if user does not exist yet.

crypt_scheme: not required, default: apr_md5_crypt. # Encryption scheme to be used.  As well as the four choices listed here, you can also use any other hash supported by passlib, such as md5_crypt and sha256_crypt, which are linux passwd hashes.  If you do so the password file will not be compatible with Apache or Nginx

iam.description: Manage IAM users, groups, roles and keys
body: iam
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
new_name: not required, default: null. # When state is update, will replace name with new_name on IAM resource
update_password: not required, default: always. # C(always) will update passwords if they differ.  C(on_create) will only set the password for newly created users.
key_count: not required, default: 1. # When access_key_state is create it will ensure this quantity of keys are present. Defaults to 1.
access_key_ids: not required, default: undefined. # A list of the keys that you want impacted by the access_key_state parameter.
groups: not required, default: null. # A list of groups the user should belong to. When update, will gracefully remove groups not listed.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.

path: not required, default: /. # When creating or updating, specify the desired path of the resource. If state is present, it will replace the current path to match what is passed in when they do not match.
password: not required, default: null. # When type is user and state is present, define the users login password. Also works with update. Note that always returns changed.
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
new_path: not required, default: null. # When state is update, will replace the path with new_path on the IAM resource
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of IAM resource to create or identify
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.
trust_policy_filepath: not required, default: null. # The path to the trust policy document that grants an entity permission to assume the role. Mutually exclusive with C(trust_policy).
access_key_state: not required, default: null. # When type is user, it creates, removes, deactivates or activates a user's access key(s). Note that actions apply only to keys specified.
iam_type: required, default: null. # Type of IAM resource
state: required, default: null. # Whether to create, delete or update the IAM resource. Note, roles cannot be updated.
trust_policy: not required, default: null. # The inline (JSON or YAML) trust policy document that grants an entity permission to assume the role. Mutually exclusive with C(trust_policy_filepath).
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

iam_cert.description: Manage server certificates for use on ELBs and CloudFront
body: iam_cert
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
new_name: not required, default: undefined. # When state is present, this will update the name of the cert.,The cert, key and cert_chain parameters will be ignored if this is defined.

dup_ok: not required, default: false. # By default the module will not upload a certificate that is already uploaded into AWS. If set to True, it will upload the certificate as long as the name is unique.
key: not required, default: undefined. # The path to, or content of the private key in PEM encoded format. As of 2.4 content is accepted. If the parameter is not a file, it is assumed to be content.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
path: not required, default: /. # When creating or updating, specify the desired path of the certificate.

cert_chain: not required, default: undefined. # The path to, or content of the CA certificate chain in PEM encoded format. As of 2.4 content is accepted. If the parameter is not a file, it is assumed to be content.
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
new_path: not required, default: undefined. # When state is present, this will update the path of the cert.,The cert, key and cert_chain parameters will be ignored if this is defined.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of certificate to add, update or remove.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether to create(or update) or delete certificate.,If new_path or new_name is defined, specifying present will attempt to make an update these.

cert: not required, default: undefined. # The path to, or content of the certificate body in PEM encoded format. As of 2.4 content is accepted. If the parameter is not a file, it is assumed to be content.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.

policy_name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the managed policy.

You can override this by specifying false which would allow for two policy objects with different names but same rules.

Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.

Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
