imc_rest.description: Manage Cisco IMC hardware through its REST API
body: imc_rest
username: not required, default: admin. # Username used to login to the switch.
protocol: not required, default: https. # Connection protocol to use.
hostname: required, default: undefined. # IP Address or hostname of Cisco IMC, resolvable by Ansible control host.

content: not required, default: undefined. # When used instead of C(path), sets the content of the API requests directly.,This may be convenient to template simple requests, for anything complex use the M(template) module.,You can collate multiple IMC XML fragments and they will be processed sequentially in a single stream, the Cisco IMC output is subsequently merged.,Parameter C(content) is mutual exclusive with parameter C(path).

timeout: not required, default: 60. # The socket level timeout in seconds.,This is the time that every single connection (every fragment) can spend. If this C(timeout) is reached, the module will fail with a C(Connection failure) indicating that C(The read operation timed out).

path: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the absolute path of the filename that includes the body of the http request being sent to the Cisco IMC REST API.,Parameter C(path) is mutual exclusive with parameter C(content).
password: not required, default: password. # The password to use for authentication.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated.,This should only set to C(no) used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
imgadm
source: not required, default: undefined. # URI for the image source.

state: required, default: undefined. # State the object operated on should be in. C(imported) is an alias for for C(present) and C(deleted) for C(absent). When set to C(vacuumed) and C(uuid) to C(*), it will remove all unused images.
force: not required, default: undefined. # Force a given operation (where supported by imgadm(1M)).
uuid: not required, default: undefined. # Image UUID. Can either be a full UUID or C(*) for all images.
type: not required, default: imgapi. # Type for image sources.
pool: not required, default: zones. # zpool to import to or delete images from.
import_playbook
free-form: not required, default: undefined. # This action allows you to specify the name of the file directly w/o any other options.

import_role.description: Import a role into a play
body: import_role
allow_duplicates: not required, default: true. # Overrides the role's metadata setting to allow using a role more than once with the same parameters.
tasks_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's tasks/ directory.
vars_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's vars/ directory.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the role to be executed.
defaults_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's defaults/ directory.
private: not required, default: None. # If True the variables from defaults/ and vars/ in a role will not be made available to the rest of the play.
import_tasks

free-form: not required, default: undefined. # This action allows you to specify the name of the file directly w/o any other options.,Any loops, conditionals and most other keywords will be applied to the included tasks, not to this statement itself.,If you need any of those to apply to this action, use M(include_tasks) instead.

include.description: include a play or task list.
body: include
free-form: not required, default: undefined. # This module allows you to specify the name of the file directly w/o any other options.
include_role
allow_duplicates: not required, default: true. # Overrides the role's metadata setting to allow using a role more than once with the same parameters.
tasks_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's tasks/ directory.
vars_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's vars/ directory.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the role to be executed.
defaults_from: not required, default: main. # File to load from a Role's defaults/ directory.
private: not required, default: None. # If True the variables from defaults/ and vars/ in a role will not be made available to the rest of the play.
include_tasks

free-form: not required, default: undefined. # This action allows you to specify the name of the file directly w/o any other options.,Unlike M(import_tasks) this action will be affected by most keywords, including loops and conditionals.

include_vars.description: Load variables from files, dynamically within a task.
body: include_vars
ignore_files: not required, default: null. # List of file names to ignore.

free-form: not required, default: undefined. # This module allows you to specify the 'file' option directly w/o any other options. There is no 'free-form' option, this is just an indicator, see example below.
files_matching: not required, default: null. # Limit the files that are loaded within any directory to this regular expression.

depth: not required, default: 0. # When using C(dir), this module will, by default, recursively go through each sub directory and load up the variables. By explicitly setting the depth, this module will only go as deep as the depth.
extensions: not required, default: yaml,yml,json. # List of file extensions to read when using C(dir).

file: not required, default: undefined. # The file name from which variables should be loaded.,If the path is relative, it will look for the file in vars/ subdirectory of a role or relative to playbook.

dir: not required, default: null. # The directory name from which the variables should be loaded.,If the path is relative, it will look for the file in vars/ subdirectory of a role or relative to playbook.
name: not required, default: null. # The name of a variable into which assign the included vars, if omitted (null) they will be made top level vars.

username: not required, default: root. # Username that will be used to authenticate against InfluxDB server
state: not required, default: present. # Determines if the database should be created or destroyed
password: not required, default: root. # Password that will be used to authenticate against InfluxDB server
database_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the database that will be created/destroyed
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address on which InfluxDB server is listening
port: not required, default: 8086. # The port on which InfluxDB server is listening
influxdb_retention_policy
username: not required, default: root. # Username that will be used to authenticate against InfluxDB server
default: required, default: undefined. # Sets the retention policy as default retention policy
database_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the database where retention policy will be created
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address on which InfluxDB server is listening
policy_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the retention policy
replication: required, default: undefined. # Determines how many independent copies of each point are stored in the cluster
duration: required, default: undefined. # Determines how long InfluxDB should keep the data
password: not required, default: root. # Password that will be used to authenticate against InfluxDB server
port: not required, default: 8086. # The port on which InfluxDB server is listening
ini_file
no_extra_spaces: not required, default: false. # Do not insert spaces before and after '=' symbol
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
option: not required, default: null. # If set (required for changing a I(value)), this is the name of the option.,May be omitted if adding/removing a whole I(section).
state: not required, default: present. # If set to C(absent) the option or section will be removed if present instead of created.

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

section: required, default: null. # Section name in INI file. This is added if C(state=present) automatically when a single value is being set.,If left empty or set to `null`, the I(option) will be placed before the first I(section). Using `null` is also required if the config format does not support sections.

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
value: not required, default: null. # The string value to be associated with an I(option). May be omitted when removing an I(option).
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
others: not required, default: undefined. # All arguments accepted by the M(file) module also work here
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
path: required, default: null. # Path to the INI-style file; this file is created if required.,Before 2.3 this option was only usable as I(dest).
backup: not required, default: no. # Create a backup file including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.
create: not required, default: yes. # If set to 'no', the module will fail if the file does not already exist. By default it will create the file if it is missing.
interfaces_file
iface: not required, default: null. # Name of the interface, required for value changes or option remove
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
option: not required, default: null. # Name of the option, required for value changes or option remove
state: not required, default: present. # If set to C(absent) the option or section will be removed if present instead of created.

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

value: not required, default: null. # If I(option) is not presented for the I(interface) and I(state) is C(present) option will be added. If I(option) already exists and is not C(pre-up), C(up), C(post-up) or C(down), it's value will be updated. C(pre-up), C(up), C(post-up) and C(down) options can't be updated, only adding new options, removing existing ones or cleaning the whole option set are supported
dest: not required, default: /etc/network/interfaces. # Path to the interfaces file
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
backup: not required, default: no. # Create a backup file including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.

ios_banner.description: Manage multiline banners on Cisco IOS devices
body: ios_banner

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
state: not required, default: present. # Specifies whether or not the configuration is present in the current devices active running configuration.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

text: not required, default: null. # The banner text that should be present in the remote device running configuration.  This argument accepts a multiline string, with no empty lines. Requires I(state=present).

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
banner: required, default: null. # Specifies which banner that should be configured on the remote device.

ios_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Cisco IOS
body: ios_command

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote ios device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.
ios_config

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

multiline_delimiter: not required, default: @. # This argument is used when pushing a multiline configuration element to the IOS device.  It specifies the character to use as the delimiting character.  This only applies to the configuration action.

force: not required, default: false. # The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.,Note this argument should be considered deprecated.  To achieve the equivalent, set the C(match=none) which is idempotent.  This argument will be removed in a future release.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

diff_against: not required, default: undefined. # When using the C(ansible-playbook --diff) command line argument the module can generate diffs against different sources.,When this option is configure as I(startup), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the startup-config.,When this option is configured as I(intended), the module will return the diff of the running-config against the configuration provided in the C(intended_config) argument.,When this option is configured as I(running), the module will return the before and after diff of the running-config with respect to any changes made to the device configuration.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

running_config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(running_config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for comparison.

diff_ignore_lines: not required, default: undefined. # Use this argument to specify one or more lines that should be ignored during the diff.  This is used for lines in the configuration that are automatically updated by the system.  This argument takes a list of regular expressions or exact line matches.

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

save_when: not required, default: never. # When changes are made to the device running-configuration, the changes are not copied to non-volatile storage by default.  Using this argument will change that before.  If the argument is set to I(always), then the running-config will always be copied to the startup-config and the I(modified) flag will always be set to True.  If the argument is set to I(modified), then the running-config will only be copied to the startup-config if it has changed since the last save to startup-config.  If the argument is set to I(never), the running-config will never be copied to the startup-config

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

intended_config: not required, default: undefined. # The C(intended_config) provides the master configuration that the node should conform to and is used to check the final running-config against.   This argument will not modify any settings on the remote device and is strictly used to check the compliance of the current device's configuration against.  When specifying this argument, the task should also modify the C(diff_against) value and set it to I(intended).

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

defaults: not required, default: false. # This argument specifies whether or not to collect all defaults when getting the remote device running config.  When enabled, the module will get the current config by issuing the command C(show running-config all).
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

save: not required, default: false. # The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.,This option is deprecated as of Ansible 2.4, use C(save_when)

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

ios_facts.description: Collect facts from remote devices running Cisco IOS
body: ios_facts

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.

gather_subset: not required, default: !config. # When supplied, this argument will restrict the facts collected to a given subset.  Possible values for this argument include all, hardware, config, and interfaces.  Can specify a list of values to include a larger subset.  Values can also be used with an initial C(M(!)) to specify that a specific subset should not be collected.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

ios_interface.description: Manage Interface on Cisco IOS network devices
body: ios_interface
neighbors: not required, default: undefined. # Check the operational state of given interface C(name) for LLDP neighbor.,The following suboptions are available.
rx_rate: not required, default: undefined. # Receiver rate in bits per second (bps).
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Interface.
duplex: not required, default: auto. # Interface link status
enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Interface link status.
mtu: not required, default: undefined. # Maximum size of transmit packet.

delay: not required, default: 10. # Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device. This wait is applicable for operational state argument which are I(state) with values C(up)/C(down), I(tx_rate) and I(rx_rate).
state: not required, default: present. # State of the Interface configuration, C(up) means present and operationally up and C(down) means present and operationally C(down)
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of Interfaces definitions.
speed: not required, default: undefined. # Interface link speed.
tx_rate: not required, default: undefined. # Transmit rate in bits per second (bps).
description: not required, default: undefined. # Description of Interface.
ios_logging
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of logging definitions.
state: not required, default: present. # State of the logging configuration.
name: not required, default: undefined. # If value of C(dest) is I(file) it indicates file-name, for I(user) it indicates username and for I(host) indicates the host name to be notified.
level: not required, default: undefined. # Set logging severity levels.
dest: not required, default: undefined. # Destination of the logs.
facility: not required, default: undefined. # Set logging facility.
size: not required, default: undefined. # Size of buffer. The acceptable value is in range from 4096 to 4294967295 bytes.

ios_ping.description: Tests reachability using ping from IOS switch
body: ios_ping

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
count: not required, default: 5. # Number of packets to send.
dest: required, default: undefined. # The IP Address or hostname (resolvable by switch) of the remote node.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.
source: not required, default: null. # The source IP Address.
state: not required, default: present. # Determines if the expected result is success or fail.
vrf: not required, default: default. # The VRF to use for forwarding.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

ios_static_route.description: Manage static IP routes on Cisco IOS network devices
body: ios_static_route
state: not required, default: present. # State of the static route configuration.
next_hop: not required, default: undefined. # Next hop IP of the static route.
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of static route definitions.
mask: not required, default: undefined. # Network prefix mask of the static route.
prefix: not required, default: undefined. # Network prefix of the static route.
admin_distance: not required, default: 1. # Admin distance of the static route.

ios_system.description: Manage the system attributes on Cisco IOS devices
body: ios_system

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
hostname: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the device hostname parameter. This option takes an ASCII string value.

lookup_source: not required, default: undefined. # Provides one or more source interfaces to use for performing DNS lookups.  The interface provided in C(lookup_source) must be a valid interface configured on the device.

domain_search: not required, default: undefined. # Provides the list of domain suffixes to append to the hostname for the purpose of doing name resolution. This argument accepts a list of names and will be reconciled with the current active configuration on the running node.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

domain_name: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the IP domain name on the remote device to the provided value. Value should be in the dotted name form and will be appended to the C(hostname) to create a fully-qualified domain name.

state: not required, default: present. # State of the configuration values in the device's current active configuration.  When set to I(present), the values should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the values should not be in the device active configuration
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.
name_servers: not required, default: undefined. # List of DNS name servers by IP address to use to perform name resolution lookups.  This argument accepts either a list of DNS servers See examples.

lookup_enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Administrative control for enabling or disabling DNS lookups.  When this argument is set to True, lookups are performed and when it is set to False, lookups are not performed.

ios_user.description: Manage the aggregate of local users on Cisco IOS device
body: ios_user

update_password: not required, default: always. # Since passwords are encrypted in the device running config, this argument will instruct the module when to change the password.  When set to C(always), the password will always be updated in the device and when set to C(on_create) the password will be updated only if the username is created.

configured_password: not required, default: undefined. # The password to be configured on the Cisco IOS device. The password needs to be provided in clear and it will be encrypted on the device. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider password).

aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # The set of username objects to be configured on the remote Cisco IOS device. The list entries can either be the username or a hash of username and properties. This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(name) argument. alias C(users).

name: not required, default: undefined. # The username to be configured on the Cisco IOS device. This argument accepts a string value and is mutually exclusive with the C(aggregate) argument. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider username).

purge: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to consider the resource definition absolute. It will remove any previously configured usernames on the device with the exception of the `admin` user (the current defined set of users).

privilege: not required, default: undefined. # The C(privilege) argument configures the privilege level of the user when logged into the system. This argument accepts integer values in the range of 1 to 15.

state: not required, default: present. # Configures the state of the username definition as it relates to the device operational configuration. When set to I(present), the username(s) should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the username(s) should not be in the device active configuration
nopassword: not required, default: undefined. # Defines the username without assigning a password. This will allow the user to login to the system without being authenticated by a password.

view: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the view for the username in the device running configuration. The argument accepts a string value defining the view name. This argument does not check if the view has been configured on the device.

ios_vrf.description: Manage the collection of VRF definitions on Cisco IOS devices
body: ios_vrf

authorize: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to enter privileged mode on the remote device before sending any commands.  If not specified, the device will attempt to execute all commands in non-privileged mode. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTHORIZE) will be used instead.
delay: not required, default: 10. # Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device.

description: not required, default: undefined. # Provides a short description of the VRF definition in the current active configuration.  The VRF definition value accepts alphanumeric characters used to provide additional information about the VRF.
interfaces: not required, default: undefined. # Identifies the set of interfaces that should be configured in the VRF.  Interfaces must be routed interfaces in order to be placed into a VRF.

auth_pass: not required, default: none. # Specifies the password to use if required to enter privileged mode on the remote device.  If I(authorize) is false, then this argument does nothing. If the value is not specified in the task, the value of environment variable C(ANSIBLE_NET_AUTH_PASS) will be used instead.

rd: not required, default: undefined. # The router-distinguisher value uniquely identifies the VRF to routing processes on the remote IOS system.  The RD value takes the form of C(A:B) where C(A) and C(B) are both numeric values.
purge: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to consider the VRF definition absolute.  It will remove any previously configured VRFs on the device.

state: not required, default: present. # Configures the state of the VRF definition as it relates to the device operational configuration.  When set to I(present), the VRF should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the VRF should not be in the device active configuration

vrfs: not required, default: undefined. # The set of VRF definition objects to be configured on the remote IOS device.  Ths list entries can either be the VRF name or a hash of VRF definitions and attributes.  This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(name) argument.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

name: not required, default: undefined. # The name of the VRF definition to be managed on the remote IOS device.  The VRF definition name is an ASCII string name used to uniquely identify the VRF.  This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(vrfs) argument

iosxr_banner.description: Manage multiline banners on Cisco IOS XR devices
body: iosxr_banner

text: not required, default: null. # The banner text that should be present in the remote device running configuration. This argument accepts a multiline string, with no empty lines. Requires I(state=present).
state: not required, default: present. # Specifies whether or not the configuration is present in the current devices active running configuration.
banner: required, default: null. # Specifies which banner that should be configured on the remote device.

iosxr_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Cisco IOS XR
body: iosxr_command

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote iosxr device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.

iosxr_config.description: Manage Cisco IOS XR configuration sections
body: iosxr_config

comment: not required, default: configured by iosxr_config. # Allows a commit description to be specified to be included when the configuration is committed.  If the configuration is not changed or committed, this argument is ignored.

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

force: not required, default: false. # The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.,Note this argument should be considered deprecated.  To achieve the equivalent, set the C(match=none) which is idempotent.  This argument will be removed in a future release.
admin: not required, default: false. # Enters into administration configuration mode for making config changes to the device.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

config: not required, default: null. # The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuration to use as the base config for comparison.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.

iosxr_facts.description: Collect facts from remote devices running IOS XR
body: iosxr_facts

gather_subset: not required, default: !config. # When supplied, this argument will restrict the facts collected to a given subset.  Possible values for this argument include all, hardware, config, and interfaces.  Can specify a list of values to include a larger subset.  Values can also be used with an initial C(M(!)) to specify that a specific subset should not be collected.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

iosxr_interface.description: Manage Interface on Cisco IOS XR network devices
body: iosxr_interface
rx_rate: not required, default: undefined. # Receiver rate in bits per second (bps).
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Interface.
duplex: not required, default: undefined. # Interface link status
enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Interface link status.
mtu: not required, default: undefined. # Maximum size of transmit packet.

delay: not required, default: 10. # Time in seconds to wait before checking for the operational state on remote device. This wait is applicable for operational state argument which are I(state) with values C(up)/C(down), I(tx_rate) and I(rx_rate).
state: not required, default: present. # State of the Interface configuration, C(up) means present and operationally up and C(down) means present and operationally C(down)
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of Interfaces definitions.
speed: not required, default: undefined. # Interface link speed.
tx_rate: not required, default: undefined. # Transmit rate in bits per second (bps).
description: not required, default: undefined. # Description of Interface.
iosxr_logging
aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # List of logging definitions.
state: not required, default: present. # State of the logging configuration.
name: not required, default: undefined. # If value of C(dest) is I(file) it indicates file-name, for I(user) it indicates username and for I(host) indicates the host name to be notified.
level: not required, default: debugging. # Set logging severity levels.
dest: not required, default: undefined. # Destination of the logs.
facility: not required, default: local7. # Set logging facility.
size: not required, default: 307200. # Size of buffer. The acceptable value is in range from 307200 to 125000000 bytes.

iosxr_system.description: Manage the system attributes on Cisco IOS XR devices
body: iosxr_system

lookup_source: not required, default: undefined. # The C(lookup_source) argument provides one or more source interfaces to use for performing DNS lookups.  The interface provided in C(lookup_source) must be a valid interface configured on the device.

domain_search: not required, default: undefined. # Provides the list of domain suffixes to append to the hostname for the purpose of doing name resolution. This argument accepts a list of names and will be reconciled with the current active configuration on the running node.
hostname: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the device hostname parameter. This option takes an ASCII string value.

domain_name: not required, default: undefined. # Configure the IP domain name on the remote device to the provided value. Value should be in the dotted name form and will be appended to the C(hostname) to create a fully-qualified domain name.

state: not required, default: present. # State of the configuration values in the device's current active configuration.  When set to I(present), the values should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the values should not be in the device active configuration
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

name_servers: not required, default: undefined. # The C(name_serves) argument accepts a list of DNS name servers by way of either FQDN or IP address to use to perform name resolution lookups.  This argument accepts wither a list of DNS servers See examples.

lookup_enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Provides administrative control for enabling or disabling DNS lookups.  When this argument is set to True, lookups are performed and when it is set to False, lookups are not performed.

iosxr_user.description: Manage the aggregate of local users on Cisco IOS XR device
body: iosxr_user

purge: not required, default: false. # Instructs the module to consider the resource definition absolute. It will remove any previously configured usernames on the device with the exception of the `admin` user (the current defined set of users).

update_password: not required, default: always. # Since passwords are encrypted in the device running config, this argument will instruct the module when to change the password.  When set to C(always), the password will always be updated in the device and when set to C(on_create) the password will be updated only if the username is created.

configured_password: not required, default: undefined. # The password to be configured on the Cisco IOS XR device. The password needs to be provided in clear and it will be encrypted on the device. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider password).

group: not required, default: undefined. # Configures the group for the username in the device running configuration. The argument accepts a string value defining the group name. This argument does not check if the group has been configured on the device, alias C(role).

name: not required, default: undefined. # The username to be configured on the Cisco IOS XR device. This argument accepts a string value and is mutually exclusive with the C(aggregate) argument. Please note that this option is not same as C(provider username).

aggregate: not required, default: undefined. # The set of username objects to be configured on the remote Cisco IOS XR device. The list entries can either be the username or a hash of username and properties. This argument is mutually exclusive with the C(name) argument, alias C(users).

state: not required, default: present. # Configures the state of the username definition as it relates to the device operational configuration. When set to I(present), the username(s) should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to I(absent) the username(s) should not be in the device active configuration
ipa_dnsrecord
ipa_port: not required, default: 443. # Port of IPA server
record_name: required, default: undefined. # The DNS record name to manage.
ipa_prot: not required, default: https. # Protocol used by IPA server
record_type: not required, default: A. # The type of DNS record name,Currently, 'A', 'AAAA', and 'PTR' are supported
state: not required, default: present. # State to ensure
ipa_host: not required, default: ipa.example.com. # IP or hostname of IPA server
ipa_user: not required, default: admin. # Administrative account used on IPA server
zone_name: required, default: undefined. # The DNS zone name to which DNS record needs to be managed.
ipa_pass: required, default: undefined. # Password of administrative user

record_value: required, default: undefined. # Manage DNS record name with this value.,In the case of 'A' or 'AAAA' record types, this will be the IP address.,In the case of 'PTR' record type, this will be the hostname.

validate_certs: not required, default: true. # This only applies if C(ipa_prot) is I(https).,If set to C(no), the SSL certificates will not be validated.,This should only set to C(no) used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
ipa_group
ipa_port: not required, default: 443. # Port of IPA server

group: not required, default: undefined. # List of group names assigned to this group.,If an empty list is passed all groups will be removed from this group.,If option is omitted assigned groups will not be checked or changed.,Groups that are already assigned but not passed will be removed.
cn: required, default: undefined. # Canonical name.,Can not be changed as it is the unique identifier.
external: not required, default: undefined. # Allow adding external non-IPA members from trusted domains.
ipa_prot: not required, default: https. # Protocol used by IPA server
gidnumber: not required, default: undefined. # GID (use this option to set it manually).
state: not required, default: present. # State to ensure

nonposix: not required, default: undefined. # Create as a non-POSIX group.

user: not required, default: undefined. # List of user names assigned to this group.,If an empty list is passed all users will be removed from this group.,If option is omitted assigned users will not be checked or changed.,Users that are already assigned but not passed will be removed.
ipa_hbacrule
sourcehostcategory: not required, default: undefined. # Source host category
cn: required, default: undefined. # Canonical name.,Can not be changed as it is the unique identifier.
ipa_port: not required, default: 443. # Port of IPA server
hostcategory: not required, default: undefined. # Host category
ipa_host: not required, default: ipa.example.com. # IP or hostname of IPA server

usergroup: not required, default: undefined. # List of user group names to assign.,If an empty list if passed all assigned user groups will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted user groups will not be checked or changed.
description: not required, default: undefined. # Description
servicecategory: not required, default: undefined. # Service category

service: not required, default: undefined. # List of service names to assign.,If an empty list is passed all services will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted services will not be checked or changed.

user: not required, default: undefined. # List of user names to assign.,If an empty list if passed all assigned users will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted users will not be checked or changed.
ipa_prot: not required, default: https. # Protocol used by IPA server
host: not required, default: undefined. # List of host names to assign.,If an empty list is passed all hosts will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted hosts will not be checked or changed.

hostgroup: not required, default: undefined. # List of hostgroup names to assign.,If an empty list is passed all hostgroups will be removed. from the rule,If option is omitted hostgroups will not be checked or changed.
usercategory: not required, default: undefined. # User category
state: not required, default: present. # State to ensure
ipa_user: not required, default: admin. # Administrative account used on IPA server
ipa_pass: required, default: undefined. # Password of administrative user

servicegroup: not required, default: undefined. # List of service group names to assign.,If an empty list is passed all assigned service groups will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted service groups will not be checked or changed.

sourcehostgroup: not required, default: undefined. # List of source host group names to assign.,If an empty list if passed all assigned source host groups will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted source host groups will not be checked or changed.

sourcehost: not required, default: undefined. # List of source host names to assign.,If an empty list if passed all assigned source hosts will be removed from the rule.,If option is omitted source hosts will not be checked or changed.
ipa_host
force: not required, default: undefined. # Force host name even if not in DNS.
description: not required, default: undefined. # A description of this host.
ns_os_version: not required, default: undefined. # Host operating system and version (e.g. "Fedora 9")
ipa_host: not required, default: ipa.example.com. # IP or hostname of IPA server
ip_address: not required, default: undefined. # Add the host to DNS with this IP address.
ns_hardware_platform: not required, default: undefined. # Host hardware platform (e.g. "Lenovo T61")
ns_host_location: not required, default: undefined. # Host location (e.g. "Lab 2")
ipa_port: not required, default: 443. # Port of IPA server

user_certificate: not required, default: undefined. # List of Base-64 encoded server certificates.,If option is omitted certificates will not be checked or changed.,If an empty list is passed all assigned certificates will be removed.,Certificates already assigned but not passed will be removed.

fqdn: required, default: undefined. # Full qualified domain name.,Can not be changed as it is the unique identifier.

ipa_pass: required, default: undefined. # Password of administrative user

hostgroup: not required, default: undefined. # List of host-groups than belong to that host-group.,If an empty list is passed all host-groups will be removed from the group.,If option is omitted host-groups will not be checked or changed.,If option is passed all assigned hostgroups that are not passed will be unassigned from the group.

description: not required, default: undefined. # Description
ipa_role

group: not required, default: undefined. # List of group names assign to this role.,If an empty list is passed all assigned groups will be unassigned from the role.,If option is omitted groups will not be checked or changed.,If option is passed all assigned groups that are not passed will be unassigned from the role.
cn: required, default: undefined. # Role name.,Can not be changed as it is the unique identifier.

privilege: not required, default: None. # List of privileges granted to the role.,If an empty list is passed all assigned privileges will be removed.,If option is omitted privileges will not be checked or changed.,If option is passed all assigned privileges that are not passed will be removed.

ipadm_addr.description: Manage IP addresses on an interface on Solaris/illumos systems
body: ipadm_addr
addrtype: not required, default: static. # Specifiies a type of IP address to configure.
state: not required, default: present. # Create/delete/enable/disable an IP address on the network interface.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the configured IP address is temporary. Temporary IP addresses do not persist across reboots.
address: not required, default: undefined. # Specifiies an IP address to configure in CIDR notation.
addrobj: required, default: undefined. # Specifies an unique IP address on the system.
wait: not required, default: 60. # Specifies the time in seconds we wait for obtaining address via DHCP.

ipadm_addrprop.description: Manage IP address properties on Solaris/illumos systems.
body: ipadm_addrprop
state: not required, default: present. # Set or reset the property value.
property: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the name of the address property we want to manage.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the address property value is temporary. Temporary values do not persist across reboots.
value: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the value we want to set for the address property.
addrobj: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the address object we want to manage.

ipadm_if.description: Manage IP interfaces  on Solaris/illumos systems.
body: ipadm_if
state: not required, default: present. # Create or delete Solaris/illumos IP interfaces.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the IP interface is temporary. Temporary IP interfaces do not persist across reboots.
name: required, default: undefined. # IP interface name.

ipadm_ifprop.description: Manage IP interface properties on Solaris/illumos systems.
body: ipadm_ifprop
state: not required, default: present. # Set or reset the property value.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the property value is temporary. Temporary property values do not persist across reboots.
interface: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the IP interface we want to manage.
protocol: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the procotol for which we want to manage properties.
property: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the name of the property we want to manage.
value: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the value we want to set for the property.

ipadm_prop.description: Manage protocol properties on Solaris/illumos systems.
body: ipadm_prop
protocol: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the procotol for which we want to manage properties.
state: not required, default: present. # Set or reset the property value.
property: required, default: undefined. # Specifies the name of property we want to manage.
temporary: not required, default: false. # Specifies that the property value is temporary. Temporary property values do not persist across reboots.
value: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the value we want to set for the property.

ipify_facts.description: Retrieve the public IP of your internet gateway.
body: ipify_facts
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to C(NO), SSL certificates will not be validated.
api_url: not required, default: https://api.ipify.org. # URL of the ipify.org API service.,C(?format=json) will be appended per default.
timeout: not required, default: 10. # HTTP connection timeout in seconds.

ipinfoio_facts.description: Retrieve IP geolocation facts of a host's IP address
body: ipinfoio_facts
http_agent: not required, default: ansible-ipinfoio-module/0.0.1. # Set http user agent
timeout: not required, default: 10. # HTTP connection timeout in seconds

ipmi_boot.description: Management of order of boot devices
body: ipmi_boot
bootdev: required, default: undefined. # Set boot device to use on next reboot
name: required, default: undefined. # Hostname or ip address of the BMC.
persistent: not required, default: false. # If set, ask that system firmware uses this device beyond next boot. Be aware many systems do not honor this.

uefiboot: not required, default: false. # If set, request UEFI boot explicitly. Strictly speaking, the spec suggests that if not set, the system should BIOS boot and offers no "don't care" option. In practice, this flag not being set does not preclude UEFI boot on any system I've encountered.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether to ensure that boot devices is desired.
user: required, default: undefined. # Username to use to connect to the BMC.
password: required, default: null. # Password to connect to the BMC.
port: not required, default: 623. # Remote RMCP port.
ipmi_power
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether to ensure that the machine in desired state.
name: required, default: undefined. # Hostname or ip address of the BMC.
timeout: not required, default: 300. # Maximum number of seconds before interrupt request.
password: required, default: null. # Password to connect to the BMC.
port: not required, default: 623. # Remote RMCP port.
user: required, default: undefined. # Username to use to connect to the BMC.
iptables

tcp_flags: not required, default: [object Object]. # TCP flags specification. tcp_flags expects a dict with the two keys "flags" and "flags_set". The "flags" list is the mask, a list of flags you want to examine. The "flags_set" list tells which one(s) should be set. If one of the two values is missing, the --tcp-flags option will be ignored.
comment: not required, default: null. # This specifies a comment that will be added to the rule

protocol: not required, default: null. # The protocol of the rule or of the packet to check. The specified protocol can be one of tcp, udp, udplite, icmp, esp, ah, sctp or the special keyword "all", or it can be a numeric value, representing one of these protocols or a different one. A protocol name from /etc/protocols is also allowed. A "!" argument before the protocol inverts the test.  The number zero is equivalent to all. "all" will match with all protocols and is taken as default when this option is omitted.

chain: not required, default: undefined. # Chain to operate on. This option can either be the name of a user defined chain or any of the builtin chains: 'INPUT', 'FORWARD', 'OUTPUT', 'PREROUTING', 'POSTROUTING', 'SECMARK', 'CONNSECMARK'.

out_interface: not required, default: null. # Name of an interface via which a packet is going to be sent (for packets entering the FORWARD, OUTPUT and POSTROUTING chains). When the "!" argument is used before the interface name, the sense is inverted. If the interface name ends in a "+", then any interface which begins with this name will match. If this option is omitted, any interface name will match.
limit_burst: not required, default: null. # Specifies the maximum burst before the above limit kicks in.

ctstate: not required, default: . # ctstate is a list of the connection states to match in the conntrack module. Possible states are: 'INVALID', 'NEW', 'ESTABLISHED', 'RELATED', 'UNTRACKED', 'SNAT', 'DNAT'

jump: not required, default: null. # This specifies the target of the rule; i.e., what to do if the packet matches it. The target can be a user-defined chain (other than the one this rule is in), one of the special builtin targets which decide the fate of the packet immediately, or an extension (see EXTENSIONS below).  If this option is omitted in a rule (and the goto parameter is not used), then matching the rule will have no effect on the packet's fate, but the counters on the rule will be incremented.

to_ports: not required, default: null. # This specifies a destination port or range of ports to use: without this, the destination port is never altered. This is only valid if the rule also specifies one of the following protocols: tcp, udp, dccp or sctp.
flush: not required, default: undefined. # Flushes the specified table and chain of all rules. If no chain is specified then the entire table is purged. Ignores all other parameters.

table: not required, default: filter. # This option specifies the packet matching table which the command should operate on. If the kernel is configured with automatic module loading, an attempt will be made to load the appropriate module for that table if it is not already there.

icmp_type: not required, default: undefined. # This allows specification of the ICMP type, which can be a numeric ICMP type, type/code pair, or one of the ICMP type names shown by the command 'iptables -p icmp -h'
to_destination: not required, default: null. # This specifies a destination address to use with DNAT: without this, the destination address is never altered.
uid_owner: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the UID or username to use in match by owner rule.

set_dscp_mark_class: not required, default: null. # This allows specifying a predefined DiffServ class which will be translated to the corresponding DSCP mark. Mutually exclusive with C(set_dscp_mark).

destination: not required, default: null. # Destination specification. Address can be either a network name, a hostname, a network IP address (with /mask), or a plain IP address. Hostnames will be resolved once only, before the rule is submitted to the kernel. Please note that specifying any name to be resolved with a remote query such as DNS is a really bad idea. The mask can be either a network mask or a plain number, specifying the number of 1's at the left side of the network mask. Thus, a mask of 24 is equivalent to 255.255.255.0. A "!" argument before the address specification inverts the sense of the address.
set_dscp_mark: not required, default: null. # This allows specifying a DSCP mark to be added to packets. It takes either an integer or hex value. Mutually exclusive with C(set_dscp_mark_class).

source: not required, default: null. # Source specification. Address can be either a network name, a hostname, a network IP address (with /mask), or a plain IP address. Hostnames will be resolved once only, before the rule is submitted to the kernel. Please note that specifying any name to be resolved with a remote query such as DNS is a really bad idea. The mask can be either a network mask or a plain number, specifying the number of 1's at the left side of the network mask. Thus, a mask of 24 is equivalent to 255.255.255.0. A "!" argument before the address specification inverts the sense of the address.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the rule should be absent or present.

policy: not required, default: undefined. # Set the policy for the chain to the given target. Valid targets are ACCEPT, DROP, QUEUE, RETURN. Only built in chains can have policies. This parameter requires the chain parameter. Ignores all other parameters.
set_counters: not required, default: null. # This enables the administrator to initialize the packet and byte counters of a rule (during INSERT, APPEND, REPLACE operations).

match: not required, default: . # Specifies a match to use, that is, an extension module that tests for a specific property. The set of matches make up the condition under which a target is invoked. Matches are evaluated first to last if specified as an array and work in short-circuit fashion, i.e. if one extension yields false, evaluation will stop.

goto: not required, default: null. # This specifies that the processing should continue in a user specified chain. Unlike the jump argument return will not continue processing in this chain but instead in the chain that called us via jump.

fragment: not required, default: null. # This means that the rule only refers to second and further fragments of fragmented packets. Since there is no way to tell the source or destination ports of such a packet (or ICMP type), such a packet will not match any rules which specify them. When the "!" argument precedes fragment argument, the rule will only match head fragments, or unfragmented packets.
to_source: not required, default: null. # This specifies a source address to use with SNAT: without this, the source address is never altered.

in_interface: not required, default: null. # Name of an interface via which a packet was received (only for packets entering the INPUT, FORWARD and PREROUTING chains). When the "!" argument is used before the interface name, the sense is inverted. If the interface name ends in a "+", then any interface which begins with this name will match. If this option is omitted, any interface name will match.

source_port: not required, default: null. # Source port or port range specification. This can either be a service name or a port number. An inclusive range can also be specified, using the format first:last. If the first port is omitted, '0' is assumed; if the last is omitted, '65535' is assumed. If the first port is greater than the second one they will be swapped.

destination_port: not required, default: null. # Destination port or port range specification. This can either be a service name or a port number. An inclusive range can also be specified, using the format first:last. If the first port is omitted, '0' is assumed; if the last is omitted, '65535' is assumed. If the first port is greater than the second one they will be swapped.
reject_with: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the error packet type to return while rejecting.

limit: not required, default: null. # Specifies the maximum average number of matches to allow per second. The number can specify units explicitly, using `/second', `/minute', `/hour' or `/day', or parts of them (so `5/second' is the same as `5/s').
action: not required, default: append. # Whether the rule should be appended at the bottom or inserted at the top. If the rule already exists the chain won't be modified.
ip_version: not required, default: ipv4. # Which version of the IP protocol this rule should apply to.

irc.description: Send a message to an IRC channel
body: irc
style: not required, default: None. # Text style for the message. Note italic does not work on some clients
key: not required, default: undefined. # Channel key
passwd: not required, default: undefined. # Server password

color: not required, default: none. # Text color for the message. ("none" is a valid option in 1.6 or later, in 1.6 and prior, the default color is black, not "none"). Added 11 more colors in version 2.0.
server: not required, default: localhost. # IRC server name/address
topic: not required, default: null. # Set the channel topic
nick: not required, default: ansible. # Nickname to send the message from. May be shortened, depending on server's NICKLEN setting.
part: not required, default: true. # Designates whether user should part from channel after sending message or not. Useful for when using a faux bot and not wanting join/parts between messages.
nick_to: not required, default: null. # A list of nicknames to send the message to. One of nick_to or channel needs to be set.  When both are defined, the message will be sent to both of them.
timeout: not required, default: 30. # Timeout to use while waiting for successful registration and join messages, this is to prevent an endless loop
msg: required, default: null. # The message body.
use_ssl: not required, default: false. # Designates whether TLS/SSL should be used when connecting to the IRC server
port: not required, default: 6667. # IRC server port number
channel: required, default: undefined. # Channel name.  One of nick_to or channel needs to be set.  When both are set, the message will be sent to both of them.

iso_extract.description: Extract files from an ISO image
body: iso_extract
dest: required, default: undefined. # The destination directory to extract files to.
files: required, default: undefined. # A list of files to extract from the image.,Extracting directories does not work.
image: required, default: undefined. # The ISO image to extract files from.

force: not required, default: yes. # If C(yes), which will replace the remote file when contents are different than the source.,If C(no), the file will only be extracted and copied if the destination does not already exist.
executable: not required, default: 7z. # The path to the C(7z) executable to use for extracting files from the ISO.

jabber.description: Send a message to jabber user or chat room
body: jabber
to: required, default: undefined. # user ID or name of the room, when using room use a slash to indicate your nick.
host: not required, default: undefined. # host to connect, overrides user info
user: required, default: undefined. # User as which to connect
encoding: not required, default: undefined. # message encoding
msg: required, default: null. # The message body.
password: required, default: undefined. # password for user to connect
port: not required, default: 5222. # port to connect to, overrides default

java_cert.description: Uses keytool to import/remove key from java keystore(cacerts)
body: java_cert
keystore_create: not required, default: undefined. # Create keystore if it doesn't exist
cert_alias: not required, default: undefined. # Imported certificate alias.
executable: not required, default: keytool. # Path to keytool binary if not used we search in PATH for it.
pkcs12_password: not required, default: . # Password for importing from PKCS12 keystore.
cert_port: not required, default: 443. # Port to connect to URL. This will be used to create server URL:PORT
pkcs12_alias: not required, default: 1. # Alias in the PKCS12 keystore.
state: not required, default: present. # Defines action which can be either certificate import or removal.
keystore_pass: required, default: undefined. # Keystore password.
pkcs12_path: not required, default: undefined. # Local path to load PKCS12 keystore from.
cert_url: not required, default: undefined. # Basic URL to fetch SSL certificate from. One of cert_url or cert_path is required to load certificate.
cert_path: not required, default: undefined. # Local path to load certificate from. One of cert_url or cert_path is required to load certificate.
keystore_path: not required, default: undefined. # Path to keystore.
jboss
src: not required, default: undefined. # The remote path of the application ear or war to deploy
deploy_path: not required, default: /var/lib/jbossas/standalone/deployments. # The location in the filesystem where the deployment scanner listens
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the application should be deployed or undeployed
deployment: required, default: undefined. # The name of the deployment
jenkins_job
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the Jenkins job.
url: not required, default: http://localhost:8080. # Url where the Jenkins server is accessible.
enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Whether the job should be enabled or disabled.,Mututally exclusive with C(config).,Considered if C(state=present).
state: not required, default: present. # Attribute that specifies if the job has to be created or deleted.
token: not required, default: undefined. # API token used to authenticate alternatively to password.
user: not required, default: undefined. # User to authenticate with the Jenkins server.
password: not required, default: undefined. # Password to authenticate with the Jenkins server.
config: not required, default: undefined. # config in XML format.,Required if job does not yet exist.,Mututally exclusive with C(enabled).,Considered if C(state=present).
jenkins_plugin
jenkins_home: not required, default: /var/lib/jenkins. # Home directory of the Jenkins user.
group: not required, default: jenkins. # Name of the Jenkins group on the OS.
name: required, default: undefined. # Plugin name.
url: not required, default: http://localhost:8080. # URL of the Jenkins server.
updates_url: not required, default: https://updates.jenkins-ci.org. # URL of the Update Centre.,Used as the base URL to download the plugins and the I(update-center.json) JSON file.
with_dependencies: not required, default: yes. # Defines whether to install plugin dependencies.,This option takes effect only if the I(version) is not defined.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired plugin state.,If the C(latest) is set, the check for new version will be performed every time. This is suitable to keep the plugin up-to-date.

version: not required, default: null. # Plugin version number.,If this option is specified, all plugin dependencies must be installed manually.,It might take longer to verify that the correct version is installed. This is especially true if a specific version number is specified.,Quote the version to prevent the value to be interpreted as float. For example if C(1.20) would be unquoted, it would become C(1.2).

params: not required, default: null. # Option used to allow the user to overwrite any of the other options. To remove an option, set the value of the option to C(null).,Changed in 2.5.0, 2.4.1, 2.3.3 to raise an error if C(url_password) is specified in params. Use the actual C(url_password) argument instead.
mode: not required, default: 0664. # File mode applied on versioned plugins.
timeout: not required, default: 30. # Server connection timeout in secs.
owner: not required, default: jenkins. # Name of the Jenkins user on the OS.

updates_expiration: not required, default: 86400. # Number of seconds after which a new copy of the I(update-center.json) file is downloaded. This is used to avoid the need to download the plugin to calculate its checksum when C(latest) is specified.,Set it to C(0) if no cache file should be used. In that case, the plugin file will always be downloaded to calculate its checksum when C(latest) is specified.

jenkins_script.description: Executes a groovy script in the jenkins instance
body: jenkins_script
password: not required, default: null. # The password to connect to the jenkins server with.
user: not required, default: null. # The username to connect to the jenkins server with.
timeout: not required, default: 10. # The request timeout in seconds
script: required, default: null. # The groovy script to be executed. This gets passed as a string Template if args is defined.
url: not required, default: http://localhost:8080. # The jenkins server to execute the script against. The default is a local jenkins instance that is not being proxied through a webserver.
