Values can also be used with an initial C(!) to specify that that specific subset should not be collected.  For instance: !hardware, !network, !virtual, !ohai, !facter. If !all is specified then only the min subset is collected. To avoid collecting even the min subset, specify !all and !min subsets. To collect only specific facts, use !all, !min, and specify the particular fact subsets. Use the filter parameter if you do not want to display some collected facts.

fact_path: not required, default: /etc/ansible/facts.d. # path used for local ansible facts (*.fact) - files in this dir will be run (if executable) and their results be added to ansible_local facts if a file is not executable it is read. Check notes for Windows options. (from 2.1 on) File/results format can be json or ini-format
gather_timeout: not required, default: 10. # Set the default timeout in seconds for individual fact gathering
sf_account_manager
username: required, default: undefined. # Please ensure that the user has the adequate permissions. For more information, please read the official documentation U(https://goo.gl/ddJa4Q).
new_name: not required, default: None. # New name for the user account.

target_secret: not required, default: undefined. # CHAP secret to use for the target (mutual CHAP authentication).,Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.,The CHAP target secrets must be unique and cannot be the same as the initiator CHAP secret.,If not specified, a random secret is created.
name: required, default: undefined. # Unique username for this account. (May be 1 to 64 characters in length).
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address of the SolidFire cluster.

initiator_secret: not required, default: undefined. # CHAP secret to use for the initiator. Should be 12-16 characters long and impenetrable.,The CHAP initiator secrets must be unique and cannot be the same as the target CHAP secret.,If not specified, a random secret is created.
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether the specified account should exist or not.
status: not required, default: undefined. # Status of the account.
attributes: not required, default: undefined. # List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for the specified user.
account_id: not required, default: None. # The ID of the account to manage or update.

sf_check_connections.description: Check connectivity to MVIP and SVIP.
body: sf_check_connections
username: required, default: undefined. # Please ensure that the user has the adequate permissions. For more information, please read the official documentation U(https://goo.gl/ddJa4Q).
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address of the SolidFire cluster.
svip: not required, default: None. # Optionally, use to test connection of a different SVIP.,This is not needed to test the connection to the target cluster.
skip: not required, default: None. # Skip checking connection to SVIP or MVIP.
mvip: not required, default: None. # Optionally, use to test connection of a different MVIP.,This is not needed to test the connection to the target cluster.
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for the specified user.
sf_snapshot_schedule_manager
username: required, default: undefined. # Please ensure that the user has the adequate permissions. For more information, please read the official documentation U(https://goo.gl/ddJa4Q).
time_interval_days: not required, default: 1. # Time interval in days.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name for the snapshot schedule.
time_interval_minutes: not required, default: 0. # Time interval in minutes.
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address of the SolidFire cluster.
schedule_id: not required, default: undefined. # The schedule ID for the schedule that you want to update or delete.
time_interval_hours: not required, default: 0. # Time interval in hours.
paused: not required, default: undefined. # Pause / Resume a schedule.
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether the specified schedule should exist or not.
snapshot_name: not required, default: undefined. # Name for the created snapshots.
volumes: not required, default: undefined. # Volume IDs that you want to set the snapshot schedule for.,At least 1 volume ID is required for creating a new schedule.,required when C(state=present)

starting_date: not required, default: undefined. # Starting date for the schedule.,Required when C(state=present).,Please use two '-' in the above format, or you may see an error- TypeError, is not JSON serializable description.,Format: C(2016--12--01T00:00:00Z)
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for the specified user.
recurring: not required, default: undefined. # Should the schedule recur?
retention: not required, default: undefined. # Retention period for the snapshot.,Format is 'HH:mm:ss'.
sf_volume_access_group_manager
username: required, default: undefined. # Please ensure that the user has the adequate permissions. For more information, please read the official documentation U(https://goo.gl/ddJa4Q).
volume_access_group_id: not required, default: None. # The ID of the volume access group to modify or delete.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the volume access group. It is not required to be unique, but recommended.
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address of the SolidFire cluster.
virtual_network_id: not required, default: None. # The ID of the SolidFire Virtual Network ID to associate the volume access group with.
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether the specified volume access group should exist or not.
volumes: not required, default: None. # List of volumes to initially include in the volume access group. If unspecified, the access group will start without any volumes.
initiators: not required, default: None. # List of initiators to include in the volume access group. If unspecified, the access group will start out without configured initiators.
attributes: not required, default: None. # List of Name/Value pairs in JSON object format.
virtual_network_tags: not required, default: None. # The ID of the VLAN Virtual Network Tag to associate the volume access group with.
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for the specified user.
sf_volume_manager
username: required, default: undefined. # Please ensure that the user has the adequate permissions. For more information, please read the official documentation U(https://goo.gl/ddJa4Q).
qos: not required, default: None. # Initial quality of service settings for this volume. Configure as dict in playbooks.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name of the volume to manage.
hostname: required, default: undefined. # The hostname or IP address of the SolidFire cluster.
size_unit: not required, default: gb. # The unit used to interpret the size parameter.

access: not required, default: None. # Access allowed for the volume.,readOnly: Only read operations are allowed.,readWrite: Reads and writes are allowed.,locked: No reads or writes are allowed.,replicationTarget: Identify a volume as the target volume for a paired set of volumes. If the volume is not paired, the access status is locked.,If unspecified, the access settings of the clone will be the same as the source.
state: required, default: undefined. # Whether the specified volume should exist or not.
size: not required, default: undefined. # The size of the volume in (size_unit).,Required when C(state = present).

volume_id: not required, default: None. # The ID of the volume to manage or update.,In order to create multiple volumes with the same name, but different volume_ids, please declare the I(volume_id) parameter with an arbitrary value. However, the specified volume_id will not be assigned to the newly created volume (since it's an auto-generated property).
512emulation: not required, default: undefined. # Should the volume provide 512-byte sector emulation?,Required when C(state=present)
attributes: not required, default: None. # A YAML dictionary of attributes that you would like to apply on this volume.
password: required, default: undefined. # Password for the specified user.
account_id: required, default: undefined. # Account ID for the owner of this volume.
shell
warn: not required, default: true. # if command warnings are on in ansible.cfg, do not warn about this particular line if set to no/false.
creates: not required, default: null. # a filename, when it already exists, this step will B(not) be run.
executable: not required, default: null. # change the shell used to execute the command. Should be an absolute path to the executable.
chdir: not required, default: null. # cd into this directory before running the command
stdin: not required, default: null. # Set the stdin of the command directly to the specified value.
removes: not required, default: null. # a filename, when it does not exist, this step will B(not) be run.
free_form: required, default: null. # The shell module takes a free form command to run, as a string.  There's not an actual option named "free form".  See the examples!

sl_vm.description: create or cancel a virtual instance in SoftLayer
body: sl_vm
domain: not required, default: null. # Domain name to be provided to a virtual instance
disks: required, default: 25. # List of disk sizes to be assigned to new virtual instance
tags: not required, default: null. # Tag or list of tags to be provided to a virtual instance
instance_id: not required, default: null. # Instance Id of the virtual instance to perform action option
dedicated: not required, default: false. # Flag to determine if the instance should be deployed in dedicated space
private: not required, default: false. # Flag to determine if the instance should be private only
cpus: required, default: null. # Count of cpus to be assigned to new virtual instance
image_id: not required, default: null. # Image Template to be used for new virtual instance
nic_speed: not required, default: 10. # NIC Speed to be assigned to new virtual instance
private_vlan: not required, default: null. # VLAN by its Id to be assigned to the private NIC
datacenter: not required, default: null. # Datacenter for the virtual instance to be deployed
public_vlan: not required, default: null. # VLAN by its Id to be assigned to the public NIC
wait: not required, default: true. # Flag used to wait for active status before returning
hourly: not required, default: true. # Flag to determine if the instance should be hourly billed
ssh_keys: not required, default: null. # List of ssh keys by their Id to be assigned to a virtual instance
hostname: not required, default: null. # Hostname to be provided to a virtual instance
os_code: not required, default: null. # OS Code to be used for new virtual instance
wait_time: not required, default: 600. # time in seconds before wait returns
local_disk: not required, default: true. # Flag to determine if local disk should be used for the new instance
state: not required, default: present. # Create, or cancel a virtual instance. Specify "present" for create, "absent" to cancel.
post_uri: not required, default: null. # URL of a post provisioning script to be loaded and executed on virtual instance
memory: required, default: null. # Amount of memory to be assigned to new virtual instance
slack
username: not required, default: Ansible. # This is the sender of the message.

domain: not required, default: None. # Slack (sub)domain for your environment without protocol. (i.e. C(example.slack.com)) In 1.8 and beyond, this is deprecated and may be ignored.  See token documentation for information.
attachments: not required, default: None. # Define a list of attachments. This list mirrors the Slack JSON API. For more information, see https://api.slack.com/docs/attachments
color: not required, default: normal. # Allow text to use default colors - use the default of 'normal' to not send a custom color bar at the start of the message
icon_url: not required, default: undefined. # Url for the message sender's icon (default C(https://www.ansible.com/favicon.ico))
parse: not required, default: None. # Setting for the message parser at Slack

token: required, default: undefined. # Slack integration token.  This authenticates you to the slack service. Prior to 1.8, a token looked like C(3Ffe373sfhRE6y42Fg3rvf4GlK).  In 1.8 and above, ansible adapts to the new slack API where tokens look like C(G922VJP24/D921DW937/3Ffe373sfhRE6y42Fg3rvf4GlK).  If tokens are in the new format then slack will ignore any value of domain.  If the token is in the old format the domain is required.  Ansible has no control of when slack will get rid of the old API.  When slack does that the old format will stop working.  ** Please keep in mind the tokens are not the API tokens but are the webhook tokens.  In slack these are found in the webhook URL which are obtained under the apps and integrations. The incoming webhooks can be added in that area.  In some cases this may be locked by your Slack admin and you must request access.  It is there that the incoming webhooks can be added.  The key is on the end of the URL given to you in that section.
icon_emoji: not required, default: None. # Emoji for the message sender. See Slack documentation for options. (if I(icon_emoji) is set, I(icon_url) will not be used)
link_names: not required, default: 1. # Automatically create links for channels and usernames in I(msg).

msg: not required, default: None. # Message to send. Note that the module does not handle escaping characters. Plain-text angle brackets and ampersands should be converted to HTML entities (e.g. & to &) before sending. See Slack's documentation (U(https://api.slack.com/docs/message-formatting)) for more.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
channel: not required, default: None. # Channel to send the message to. If absent, the message goes to the channel selected for the I(token).
slackpkg
state: not required, default: present. # state of the package, you can use "installed" as an alias for C(present) and removed as one for C(absent).
update_cache: not required, default: false. # update the package database first
name: required, default: undefined. # name of package to install/remove

slurp.description: Slurps a file from remote nodes
body: slurp
src: required, default: undefined. # The file on the remote system to fetch. This I(must) be a file, not a directory.
smartos_image_facts

filters: not required, default: None. # Criteria for selecting image. Can be any value from image manifest and 'published_date', 'published', 'source', 'clones', and 'size'. More informaton can be found at U(https://smartos.org/man/1m/imgadm) under 'imgadm list'.

snmp_facts.description: Retrieve facts for a device using SNMP.
body: snmp_facts
username: not required, default: undefined. # Username for SNMPv3, required if version is v3
level: not required, default: undefined. # Authentication level, required if version is v3
privacy: not required, default: undefined. # Encryption algorithm, required if level is authPriv
community: not required, default: undefined. # The SNMP community string, required if version is v2/v2c
authkey: not required, default: undefined. # Authentication key, required if version is v3
host: required, default: undefined. # Set to target snmp server (normally {{inventory_hostname}})
version: required, default: undefined. # SNMP Version to use, v2/v2c or v3
integrity: not required, default: undefined. # Hashing algorithm, required if version is v3
privkey: not required, default: undefined. # Encryption key, required if version is authPriv

sns.description: Send Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) messages
body: sns
aws_secret_key: not required, default: None. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
aws_access_key: not required, default: None. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
http: not required, default: undefined. # Message to send to HTTP-only subscription
sqs: not required, default: undefined. # Message to send to SQS-only subscription
region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used.
sms: not required, default: undefined. # Message to send to SMS-only subscription
topic: required, default: undefined. # The topic you want to publish to.
https: not required, default: undefined. # Message to send to HTTPS-only subscription
msg: required, default: undefined. # Default message to send.

message_attributes: not required, default: None. # Dictionary of message attributes. These are optional structured data entries to be sent along to the endpoint.,This is in AWS's distinct Name/Type/Value format; see example below.
email: not required, default: undefined. # Message to send to email-only subscription

message_structure: required, default: json. # The payload format to use for the message.,This must be 'json' to support non-default messages (`http`, `https`, `email`, `sms`, `sqs`). It must be 'string' to support message_attributes.
subject: not required, default: undefined. # Subject line for email delivery.

sns_topic.description: Manages AWS SNS topics and subscriptions
body: sns_topic
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
display_name: not required, default: None. # Display name of the topic
name: required, default: undefined. # The name or ARN of the SNS topic to converge
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.
subscriptions: not required, default: . # List of subscriptions to apply to the topic. Note that AWS requires subscriptions to be confirmed, so you will need to confirm any new subscriptions.
delivery_policy: not required, default: None. # Delivery policy to apply to the SNS topic
state: not required, default: present. # Whether to create or destroy an SNS topic

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
policy: not required, default: None. # Policy to apply to the SNS topic

purge_subscriptions: not required, default: true. # Whether to purge any subscriptions not listed here. NOTE: AWS does not allow you to purge any PendingConfirmation subscriptions, so if any exist and would be purged, they are silently skipped. This means that somebody could come back later and confirm the subscription. Sorry. Blame Amazon.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.
solaris_zone

install_options: not required, default: empty string. # Extra options to the zoneadm(1M) install command. To automate Solaris 11 zone creation, use this to specify the profile XML file, e.g. install_options="-c sc_profile.xml"
name: required, default: undefined. # Zone name.
sparse: not required, default: false. # Whether to create a sparse (C(true)) or whole root (C(false)) zone.
create_options: not required, default: empty string. # Extra options to the zonecfg(1M) create command.

state: required, default: present. # C(present), configure and install the zone.,C(installed), synonym for C(present).,C(running), if the zone already exists, boot it, otherwise, configure and install the zone first, then boot it.,C(started), synonym for C(running).,C(stopped), shutdown a zone.,C(absent), destroy the zone.,C(configured), configure the ready so that it's to be attached.,C(attached), attach a zone, but do not boot it.,C(detached), shutdown and detach a zone
root_password: not required, default: null. # The password hash for the root account. If not specified, the zone's root account will not have a password.
timeout: not required, default: 600. # Timeout, in seconds, for zone to boot.
path: not required, default: null. # The path where the zone will be created. This is required when the zone is created, but not used otherwise.

config: not required, default: empty string. # The zonecfg configuration commands for this zone. See zonecfg(1M) for the valid options and syntax. Typically this is a list of options separated by semi-colons or new lines, e.g. "set auto-boot=true;add net;set physical=bge0;set address=10.1.1.1;end"

attach_options: not required, default: empty string. # Extra options to the zoneadm attach command. For example, this can be used to specify whether a minimum or full update of packages is required and if any packages need to be deleted. For valid values, see zoneadm(1M)

sorcery.description: Package manager for Source Mage GNU/Linux
body: sorcery

depends: not required, default: null. # Comma-separated list of _optional_ dependencies to build a spell (or make sure it is built) with; use +/- in front of dependency to turn it on/off ('+' is optional though),this option is ignored if C(name) parameter is equal to '*' or contains more than one spell,providers must be supplied in the form recognized by Sorcery, e.g. 'openssl(SSL)'
update_cache: not required, default: no. # Whether or not to update grimoire collection before casting spells

name: not required, default: null. # Name of the spell,multiple names can be given, separated by commas,special value '*' in conjunction with states C(latest) or C(rebuild) will update or rebuild the whole system respectively

state: not required, default: present. # Whether to cast, dispel or rebuild a package,state C(cast) is an equivalent of C(present), not C(latest),state C(latest) always triggers C(update_cache=yes),state C(rebuild) implies cast of all specified spells, not only those existed before
update: not required, default: no. # Whether or not to update sorcery scripts at the very first stage

cache_valid_time: not required, default: null. # Time in seconds to invalidate grimoire collection on update,especially useful for SCM and rsync grimoires,makes sense only in pair with C(update_cache)

sqs_queue.description: Creates or deletes AWS SQS queues.
body: sqs_queue
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
message_retention_period: not required, default: null. # The message retention period in seconds.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
delivery_delay: not required, default: null. # The delivery delay in seconds.
receive_message_wait_time: not required, default: null. # The receive message wait time in seconds.
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the queue.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.
default_visibility_timeout: not required, default: null. # The default visibility timeout in seconds.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)
state: not required, default: present. # Create or delete the queue
maximum_message_size: not required, default: null. # The maximum message size in bytes.
policy: not required, default: null. # The json dict policy to attach to queue
redrive_policy: not required, default: null. # json dict with the redrive_policy (see example)

sros_command.description: Run commands on remote devices running Nokia SR OS
body: sros_command

retries: not required, default: 10. # Specifies the number of retries a command should by tried before it is considered failed. The command is run on the target device every retry and evaluated against the I(wait_for) conditions.

commands: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to send to the remote SR OS device over the configured provider. The resulting output from the command is returned. If the I(wait_for) argument is provided, the module is not returned until the condition is satisfied or the number of retries has expired.

interval: not required, default: 1. # Configures the interval in seconds to wait between retries of the command. If the command does not pass the specified conditions, the interval indicates how long to wait before trying the command again.
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

wait_for: not required, default: null. # List of conditions to evaluate against the output of the command. The task will wait for each condition to be true before moving forward. If the conditional is not true within the configured number of retries, the task fails. See examples.

match: not required, default: all. # The I(match) argument is used in conjunction with the I(wait_for) argument to specify the match policy.  Valid values are C(all) or C(any).  If the value is set to C(all) then all conditionals in the wait_for must be satisfied.  If the value is set to C(any) then only one of the values must be satisfied.

sros_config.description: Manage Nokia SR OS device configuration
body: sros_config

src: not required, default: null. # Specifies the source path to the file that contains the configuration or configuration template to load.  The path to the source file can either be the full path on the Ansible control host or a relative path from the playbook or role root directory.  This argument is mutually exclusive with I(lines).

force: not required, default: false. # The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.,Note this argument should be considered deprecated.  To achieve the equivalent, set the C(match=none) which is idempotent.  This argument will be removed in a future release.

config: not required, default: null. # The C(config) argument allows the playbook designer to supply the base configuration to be used to validate configuration changes necessary.  If this argument is provided, the module will not download the running-config from the remote node.

after: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a change needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.  The I(lines) argument only supports current context lines.  See EXAMPLES

replace: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct.

parents: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

defaults: not required, default: false. # This argument specifies whether or not to collect all defaults when getting the remote device running config.  When enabled, the module will get the current config by issuing the command C(show running-config all).
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

save: not required, default: false. # The C(save) argument instructs the module to save the running- config to the startup-config at the conclusion of the module running.  If check mode is specified, this argument is ignored.

backup: not required, default: false. # This argument will cause the module to create a full backup of the current C(running-config) from the remote device before any changes are made.  The backup file is written to the C(backup) folder in the playbook root directory.  If the directory does not exist, it is created.

match: not required, default: line. # Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  If match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.  Finally, if match is set to I(none), the module will not attempt to compare the source configuration with the running configuration on the remote device.

before: not required, default: null. # The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system.
sros_rollback

state: not required, default: present. # The I(state) argument specifies the state of the configuration entries in the devices active configuration.  When the state value is set to C(true) the configuration is present in the devices active configuration.  When the state value is set to C(false) the configuration values are removed from the devices active configuration.
rescue_location: not required, default: null. # The I(rescue_location) specifies the location of the rescue file.  This argument supports any valid local or remote URL as specified in SR OS

remote_max_checkpoints: not required, default: null. # The I(remote_max_checkpoints) argument configures the maximum number of rollback files that can be transferred and saved to a remote location.  Valid values for this argument are in the range of 1 to 50
provider: not required, default: null. # A dict object containing connection details.

local_max_checkpoints: not required, default: null. # The I(local_max_checkpoints) argument configures the maximum number of rollback files that can be saved on the devices local compact flash.  Valid values for this argument are in the range of 1 to 50

rollback_location: not required, default: null. # The I(rollback_location) specifies the location and filename of the rollback checkpoint files.   This argument supports any valid local or remote URL as specified in SR OS

stackdriver.description: Send code deploy and annotation events to stackdriver
body: stackdriver
repository: not required, default: null. # The repository (or project) deployed
level: not required, default: INFO. # one of INFO/WARN/ERROR, defaults to INFO if not supplied. May affect display.
annotated_by: not required, default: Ansible. # The person or robotwho the annotation should be attributed to.
deployed_to: not required, default: null. # The environment code was deployed to. (ie: development, staging, production)
deployed_by: not required, default: Ansible. # The person or robot responsible for deploying the code
instance_id: not required, default: null. # id of an EC2 instance that this event should be attached to, which will limit the contexts where this event is shown
key: required, default: null. # API key.
msg: not required, default: null. # The contents of the annotation message, in plain text. Limited to 256 characters. Required for annotation.
event_epoch: not required, default: null. # Unix timestamp of where the event should appear in the timeline, defaults to now. Be careful with this.
revision_id: not required, default: null. # The revision of the code that was deployed. Required for deploy events
event: not required, default: null. # The type of event to send, either annotation or deploy

stacki_host.description: Add or remove host to stacki front-end
body: stacki_host
prim_intf_ip: not required, default: undefined. # IP Address for the primary network interface.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the host to be added to Stacki.
stacki_user: required, default: undefined. # Username for authenticating with Stacki API, but if not specified, the environment variable C(stacki_user) is used instead.
stacki_endpoint: required, default: undefined. # URL for the Stacki API Endpoint.
prim_intf: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the primary network interface.
stacki_password: required, default: undefined. # Password for authenticating with Stacki API, but if not specified, the environment variable C(stacki_password) is used instead.
force_install: not required, default: undefined. # Set value to True to force node into install state if it already exists in stacki.
prim_intf_mac: not required, default: undefined. # MAC Address for the primary PXE boot network interface.

stat.description: Retrieve file or file system status
body: stat
get_checksum: not required, default: yes. # Whether to return a checksum of the file (default sha1).
follow: not required, default: no. # Whether to follow symlinks.
checksum_algorithm: not required, default: sha1. # Algorithm to determine checksum of file. Will throw an error if the host is unable to use specified algorithm.
path: required, default: undefined. # The full path of the file/object to get the facts of.

get_mime: not required, default: yes. # Use file magic and return data about the nature of the file. this uses the 'file' utility found on most Linux/Unix systems.,This will add both `mime_type` and 'charset' fields to the return, if possible.,In 2.3 this option changed from 'mime' to 'get_mime' and the default changed to 'Yes'.
get_md5: not required, default: yes. # Whether to return the md5 sum of the file.,Will return None if not a regular file or if we're unable to use md5 (Common for FIPS-140 compliant systems).
get_attributes: not required, default: yes. # Get file attributes using lsattr tool if present.

statusio_maintenance.description: Create maintenance windows for your status.io dashboard
body: statusio_maintenance
maintenance_notify_72_hr: not required, default: false. # Notify subscribers 72 hours before maintenance start time
maintenance_notify_now: not required, default: false. # Notify subscribers now
start_time: not required, default: None. # Time maintenance is expected to start (Hour:Minutes) (UTC),End Time is worked out from start_time + minutes
api_id: required, default: undefined. # Your unique API ID from status.io
automation: not required, default: false. # Automatically start and end the maintenance window
maintenance_notify_24_hr: not required, default: false. # Notify subscribers 24 hours before maintenance start time
all_infrastructure_affected: not required, default: false. # If it affects all components and containers
maintenance_id: not required, default: None. # The maintenance id number when deleting a maintenance window
desc: not required, default: Created by Ansible. # Message describing the maintenance window
maintenance_notify_1_hr: not required, default: false. # Notify subscribers 1 hour before maintenance start time
title: not required, default: A new maintenance window. # A descriptive title for the maintenance window
url: not required, default: https://api.status.io. # Status.io API URL. A private apiary can be used instead.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the package.
components: not required, default: None. # The given name of your component (server name)
statuspage: required, default: undefined. # Your unique StatusPage ID from status.io
api_key: required, default: undefined. # Your unique API Key from status.io
minutes: not required, default: 10. # The length of time in UTC that the maintenance will run             (starting from playbook runtime)
start_date: not required, default: None. # Date maintenance is expected to start (Month/Day/Year) (UTC),End Date is worked out from start_date + minutes
containers: not required, default: None. # The given name of your container (data center)

sts_assume_role.description: Assume a role using AWS Security Token Service and obtain temporary credentials
body: sts_assume_role
aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

role_arn: required, default: undefined. # The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role that the caller is assuming (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/Using_Identifiers.html#Identifiers_ARNs)
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

duration_seconds: not required, default: null. # The duration, in seconds, of the role session. The value can range from 900 seconds (15 minutes) to 3600 seconds (1 hour). By default, the value is set to 3600 seconds.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)
role_session_name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the role's session - will be used by CloudTrail
mfa_token: not required, default: null. # The value provided by the MFA device, if the trust policy of the role being assumed requires MFA.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
policy: not required, default: null. # Supplemental policy to use in addition to assumed role's policies.
external_id: not required, default: null. # A unique identifier that is used by third parties to assume a role in their customers' accounts.
mfa_serial_number: not required, default: null. # he identification number of the MFA device that is associated with the user who is making the AssumeRole call.

sts_session_token.description: Obtain a session token from the AWS Security Token Service

aws_secret_key: not required, default: null. # AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SECRET_KEY, or EC2_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.
profile: not required, default: null. # Uses a boto profile. Only works with boto >= 2.24.0.
aws_access_key: not required, default: null. # AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_ACCESS_KEY or EC2_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.
security_token: not required, default: null. # AWS STS security token. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN or EC2_SECURITY_TOKEN environment variable is used.

duration_seconds: not required, default: null. # The duration, in seconds, of the session token. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/STS/latest/APIReference/API_GetSessionToken.html#API_GetSessionToken_RequestParameters for acceptable and default values.

region: not required, default: undefined. # The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the AWS_REGION or EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html#ec2_region)
mfa_token: not required, default: null. # The value provided by the MFA device, if the trust policy of the user requires MFA.

ec2_url: not required, default: null. # Url to use to connect to EC2 or your Eucalyptus cloud (by default the module will use EC2 endpoints). Ignored for modules where region is required. Must be specified for all other modules if region is not used. If not set then the value of the EC2_URL environment variable, if any, is used.
validate_certs: not required, default: yes. # When set to "no", SSL certificates will not be validated for boto versions >= 2.6.0.
mfa_serial_number: not required, default: null. # The identification number of the MFA device that is associated with the user who is making the GetSessionToken call.
subversion
username: not required, default: null. # --username parameter passed to svn.
executable: not required, default: null. # Path to svn executable to use. If not supplied, the normal mechanism for resolving binary paths will be used.
force: not required, default: no. # If C(yes), modified files will be discarded. If C(no), module will fail if it encounters modified files. Prior to 1.9 the default was `yes`.
dest: required, default: null. # Absolute path where the repository should be deployed.
update: not required, default: yes. # If no, do not retrieve new revisions from the origin repository
repo: required, default: null. # The subversion URL to the repository.
switch: not required, default: yes. # If C(no), do not call svn switch before update.
export: not required, default: no. # If C(yes), do export instead of checkout/update.
password: not required, default: null. # --password parameter passed to svn.
checkout: not required, default: yes. # If no, do not check out the repository if it does not exist locally
revision: not required, default: HEAD. # Specific revision to checkout.

supervisorctl.description: Manage the state of a program or group of programs running via supervisord
body: supervisorctl
username: not required, default: null. # username to use for authentication
state: required, default: null. # The desired state of program/group.
supervisorctl_path: not required, default: null. # path to supervisorctl executable

name: required, default: null. # The name of the supervisord program or group to manage.,The name will be taken as group name when it ends with a colon I(:),Group support is only available in Ansible version 1.6 or later.
password: not required, default: null. # password to use for authentication
config: not required, default: null. # The supervisor configuration file path
server_url: not required, default: null. # URL on which supervisord server is listening
svc
service_dir: not required, default: /service. # directory svscan watches for services
name: required, default: undefined. # Name of the service to manage.
downed: not required, default: false. # Should a 'down' file exist or not, if it exists it disables auto startup. defaults to no. Downed does not imply stopped.
enabled: not required, default: undefined. # Wheater the service is enabled or not, if disabled it also implies stopped. Make note that a service can be enabled and downed (no auto restart).

state: not required, default: undefined. # C(Started)/C(stopped) are idempotent actions that will not run commands unless necessary.  C(restarted) will always bounce the svc (svc -t) and C(killed) will always bounce the svc (svc -k). C(reloaded) will send a sigusr1 (svc -1). C(once) will run a normally downed svc once (svc -o), not really an idempotent operation.
service_src: not required, default: undefined. # directory where services are defined, the source of symlinks to service_dir.
svr4pkg
category: not required, default: undefined. # Install/Remove category instead of a single package.

src: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the location to install the package from. Required when C(state=present).,Can be any path acceptable to the C(pkgadd) command's C(-d) option. e.g.: C(somefile.pkg), C(/dir/with/pkgs), C(http:/server/mypkgs.pkg).,If using a file or directory, they must already be accessible by the host. See the M(copy) module for a way to get them there.

state: required, default: undefined. # Whether to install (C(present)), or remove (C(absent)) a package.,If the package is to be installed, then I(src) is required.,The SVR4 package system doesn't provide an upgrade operation. You need to uninstall the old, then install the new package.
name: required, default: undefined. # Package name, e.g. C(SUNWcsr)

zone: not required, default: all. # Whether to install the package only in the current zone, or install it into all zones.,The installation into all zones works only if you are working with the global zone.
response_file: not required, default: undefined. # Specifies the location of a response file to be used if package expects input on install. (added in Ansible 1.4)
proxy: not required, default: undefined. # HTTP[s] proxy to be used if C(src) is a URL.

swdepot.description: Manage packages with swdepot package manager (HP-UX)
body: swdepot
state: required, default: null. # whether to install (C(present), C(latest)), or remove (C(absent)) a package.
depot: not required, default: null. # The source repository from which install or upgrade a package.
name: required, default: null. # package name.

swupd.description: Manages updates and bundles in ClearLinux systems.
body: swupd
contenturl: not required, default: null. # URL pointing to the contents of available bundles. If not specified, the contents are retrieved from clearlinux.org.
name: not required, default: null. # Name of the (I)bundle to install or remove.
format: not required, default: null. # The format suffix for version file downloads. For example [1,2,3,staging,etc]. If not specified, the default format is used.
url: not required, default: null. # Overrides both I(contenturl) and I(versionurl).
verify: not required, default: null. # Verify content for OS version.
update: not required, default: false. # Updates the OS to the latest version.

manifest: not required, default: null. # The manifest contains information about the bundles at certaion version of the OS. Specify a Manifest version to verify against that version or leave unspecified to verify against the current version.
state: not required, default: present. # Indicates the desired (I)bundle state. C(present) ensures the bundle is installed while C(absent) ensures the (I)bundle is not installed.
versionurl: not required, default: null. # URL for version string download.

synchronize.description: A wrapper around rsync to make common tasks in your playbooks quick and easy.
body: synchronize
dirs: not required, default: no. # Transfer directories without recursing
partial: not required, default: false. # Tells rsync to keep the partial file which should make a subsequent transfer of the rest of the file much faster.
links: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Copy symlinks as symlinks.
copy_links: not required, default: no. # Copy symlinks as the item that they point to (the referent) is copied, rather than the symlink.
perms: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Preserve permissions.
compress: not required, default: yes. # Compress file data during the transfer. In most cases, leave this enabled unless it causes problems.
rsync_timeout: not required, default: 0. # Specify a --timeout for the rsync command in seconds.
rsync_opts: not required, default: null. # Specify additional rsync options by passing in an array.
owner: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Preserve owner (super user only)

set_remote_user: not required, default: true. # put user@ for the remote paths. If you have a custom ssh config to define the remote user for a host that does not match the inventory user, you should set this parameter to "no".
times: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Preserve modification times
rsync_path: not required, default: undefined. # Specify the rsync command to run on the remote host. See C(--rsync-path) on the rsync man page.

dest_port: not required, default: Value of ansible_ssh_port for this host, remote_port config setting, or the value from ssh client configuration if none of those are set. # Port number for ssh on the destination host. Prior to ansible 2.0, the ansible_ssh_port inventory var took precedence over this value.
src: required, default: undefined. # Path on the source host that will be synchronized to the destination; The path can be absolute or relative.
group: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Preserve group
existing_only: not required, default: no. # Skip creating new files on receiver.
recursive: not required, default: the value of the archive option. # Recurse into directories.
archive: not required, default: yes. # Mirrors the rsync archive flag, enables recursive, links, perms, times, owner, group flags and -D.
dest: required, default: undefined. # Path on the destination host that will be synchronized from the source; The path can be absolute or relative.
mode: not required, default: push. # Specify the direction of the synchronization. In push mode the localhost or delegate is the source; In pull mode the remote host in context is the source.
checksum: not required, default: no. # Skip based on checksum, rather than mod-time & size; Note that that "archive" option is still enabled by default - the "checksum" option will not disable it.
verify_host: not required, default: false. # Verify destination host key.
use_ssh_args: not required, default: no. # Use the ssh_args specified in ansible.cfg
delete: not required, default: no. # Delete files in C(dest) that don't exist (after transfer, not before) in the C(src) path. This option requires C(recursive=yes).
sysctl
reload: not required, default: yes. # If C(yes), performs a I(/sbin/sysctl -p) if the C(sysctl_file) is updated. If C(no), does not reload I(sysctl) even if the C(sysctl_file) is updated.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the entry should be present or absent in the sysctl file.
name: required, default: null. # The dot-separated path (aka I(key)) specifying the sysctl variable.
sysctl_set: not required, default: false. # Verify token value with the sysctl command and set with -w if necessary
ignoreerrors: not required, default: false. # Use this option to ignore errors about unknown keys.
sysctl_file: not required, default: /etc/sysctl.conf. # Specifies the absolute path to C(sysctl.conf), if not C(/etc/sysctl.conf).
value: not required, default: null. # Desired value of the sysctl key.
syslogger
msg: required, default: undefined. # This is the message to place in syslog
priority: not required, default: info. # Set the log priority
facility: not required, default: daemon. # Set the log facility
log_pid: not required, default: no. # Log the pid in brackets
systemd
masked: not required, default: null. # Whether the unit should be masked or not, a masked unit is impossible to start.

state: not required, default: null. # C(started)/C(stopped) are idempotent actions that will not run commands unless necessary. C(restarted) will always bounce the service. C(reloaded) will always reload.
no_block: not required, default: false. # Do not synchronously wait for the requested operation to finish. Enqueued job will continue without Ansible blocking on its completion.
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the service. When using in a chroot environment you always need to specify the full name i.e. (crond.service).
enabled: not required, default: null. # Whether the service should start on boot. B(At least one of state and enabled are required.)
daemon_reload: not required, default: false. # run daemon-reload before doing any other operations, to make sure systemd has read any changes.
user: not required, default: false. # run systemctl talking to the service manager of the calling user, rather than the service manager of the system.

taiga_issue.description: Creates/deletes an issue in a Taiga Project Management Platform
body: taiga_issue
status: not required, default: New. # The issue status. Must exist previously.
project: required, default: undefined. # Name of the project containing the issue. Must exist previously.
severity: not required, default: Normal. # The issue severity. Must exist previously.
tags: not required, default: . # A lists of tags to be assigned to the issue.
priority: not required, default: Normal. # The issue priority. Must exist previously.
taiga_host: not required, default: https://api.taiga.io. # The hostname of the Taiga instance.
state: not required, default: present. # Whether the issue should be present or not.
attachment: not required, default: None. # Path to a file to be attached to the issue.
issue_type: required, default: undefined. # The issue type. Must exist previously.
subject: required, default: undefined. # The issue subject.
attachment_description: not required, default: . # A string describing the file to be attached to the issue.
description: not required, default: . # The issue description.

telegram.description: module for sending notifications via telegram
body: telegram
msg: required, default: undefined. # What message you wish to send.

msg_format: not required, default: plain. # Message format. Formatting options `markdown` and `html` described in Telegram API docs (https://core.telegram.org/bots/api#formatting-options). If option `plain` set, message will not be formatted.
token: required, default: undefined. # Token identifying your telegram bot.
chat_id: required, default: undefined. # Telegram group or user chat_id

telnet.description: Executes a low-down and dirty telnet command
body: telnet
pause: not required, default: 1. # Seconds to pause between each command issued
host: not required, default: remote_addr. # The host/target on which to execute the command
prompts: not required, default: $. # List of prompts expected before sending next command
command: required, default: undefined. # List of commands to be executed in the telnet session.
user: not required, default: remote_user. # The user for login
timeout: not required, default: 120. # timeout for remote operations
password: not required, default: undefined. # The password for login
port: not required, default: 23. # Remote port to use
tempfile
path: not required, default: null. # Location where temporary file or directory should be created. If path is not specified default system temporary directory will be used.
state: not required, default: file. # Whether to create file or directory.
prefix: not required, default: ansible.. # Prefix of file/directory name created by module.
suffix: not required, default: . # Suffix of file/directory name created by module.

template.description: Templates a file out to a remote server
body: template

force: not required, default: yes. # the default is C(yes), which will replace the remote file when contents are different than the source.  If C(no), the file will only be transferred if the destination does not exist.
trim_blocks: not required, default: no. # If this is set to True the first newline after a block is removed (block, not variable tag!).
dest: required, default: undefined. # Location to render the template to on the remote machine.
selevel: not required, default: s0. # Level part of the SELinux file context. This is the MLS/MCS attribute, sometimes known as the C(range). C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
block_end_string: not required, default: %}. # The string marking the end of a block.
variable_start_string: not required, default: {{. # The string marking the beginning of a print statement.
block_start_string: not required, default: {%. # The string marking the beginning of a block.
variable_end_string: not required, default: }}. # The string marking the end of a print statement.
owner: not required, default: null. # Name of the user that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).
follow: not required, default: no. # This flag indicates that filesystem links in the destination, if they exist, should be followed.,Previous to Ansible 2.4, this was hardcoded as C(yes).

validate: not required, default: None. # The validation command to run before copying into place. The path to the file to validate is passed in via '%s' which must be present as in the example below. The command is passed securely so shell features like expansion and pipes won't work.
src: required, default: undefined. # Path of a Jinja2 formatted template on the Ansible controller. This can be a relative or absolute path.
group: not required, default: null. # Name of the group that should own the file/directory, as would be fed to I(chown).

unsafe_writes: not required, default: false. # Normally this module uses atomic operations to prevent data corruption or inconsistent reads from the target files, sometimes systems are configured or just broken in ways that prevent this. One example are docker mounted files, they cannot be updated atomically and can only be done in an unsafe manner.,This boolean option allows ansible to fall back to unsafe methods of updating files for those cases in which you do not have any other choice. Be aware that this is subject to race conditions and can lead to data corruption.

seuser: not required, default: null. # User part of SELinux file context. Will default to system policy, if applicable. If set to C(_default), it will use the C(user) portion of the policy if available.
setype: not required, default: null. # Type part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
serole: not required, default: null. # Role part of SELinux file context, C(_default) feature works as for I(seuser).
newline_sequence: not required, default: \n. # Specify the newline sequence to use for templating files.

mode: not required, default: null. # Mode the file or directory should be. For those used to I(/usr/bin/chmod) remember that modes are actually octal numbers (like 0644). Leaving off the leading zero will likely have unexpected results. As of version 1.8, the mode may be specified as a symbolic mode (for example, C(u+rwx) or C(u=rw,g=r,o=r)).

attributes: not required, default: None. # Attributes the file or directory should have. To get supported flags look at the man page for I(chattr) on the target system. This string should contain the attributes in the same order as the one displayed by I(lsattr).
backup: not required, default: no. # Create a backup file including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.
timezone

hwclock: not required, default: undefined. # Whether the hardware clock is in UTC or in local timezone. Default is to keep current setting. Note that this option is recommended not to change and may fail to configure, especially on virtual environments such as AWS. B(At least one of name and hwclock are required.) I(Only used on Linux.)
name: not required, default: undefined. # Name of the timezone for the system clock. Default is to keep current setting. B(At least one of name and hwclock are required.)

tower_credential.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower credential.
body: tower_credential
authorize: not required, default: false. # Should use authroize for net type.
username: not required, default: null. # Username for this credential. access_key for AWS.
domain: not required, default: null. # Domain for openstack type.
description: not required, default: undefined. # The description to use for the credential.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
vault_password: not required, default: undefined. # Valut password. Use ASK for prompting.
team: not required, default: null. # Team that should own this credential.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
host: not required, default: null. # Host for this credential.
user: not required, default: null. # User that should own this credential.
become_password: not required, default: null. # Become password. Use ASK for prompting.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
become_username: not required, default: null. # Become username. Use ASK for prompting.
password: not required, default: null. # Password for this credential. Use ASK for prompting. secret_key for AWS. api_key for RAX.
tenant: not required, default: null. # Tenant ID for azure_rm type.
subscription: not required, default: null. # Subscription ID for azure_rm type.
kind: required, default: undefined. # Type of credential being added.
become_method: not required, default: None. # Become method to Use for privledge escalation.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name to use for the credential.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
secret: not required, default: null. # Secret token for azure_rm type.
project: not required, default: null. # Project that should for this credential.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource.
client: not required, default: null. # Client or application ID for azure_rm type.
ssh_key_data: not required, default: null. # Path to SSH private key.
ssh_key_unlock: not required, default: undefined. # Unlock password for ssh_key. Use ASK for prompting.
organization: not required, default: null. # Organization that should own the credential.
authorize_password: not required, default: null. # Password for net credentials that require authroize.

tower_group.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower group.
body: tower_group
credential: not required, default: null. # Credential to use for the group.
description: not required, default: null. # The description to use for the group.
overwrite_vars: not required, default: null. # Override vars in child groups and hosts with those from external source.
source_regions: not required, default: null. # Regions for cloud provider.
variables: not required, default: null. # Variables to use for the group, use '@' for a file.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
overwrite: not required, default: false. # Delete child roups and hosts not found in source.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name to use for the group.
source_vars: not required, default: null. # Override variables from source with variables from this field.
source_script: not required, default: null. # Inventory script to be used when group type is "custom".
update_on_launch: not required, default: false. # Refresh inventory data from its source each time a job is run.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
instance_filters: not required, default: null. # Comma-separated list of filter expressions for matching hosts.
source: not required, default: null,. # The source to use for this group.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource.
group_by: not required, default: null. # Limit groups automatically created from inventory source.
inventory: required, default: undefined. # Inventory the group should be made a member of.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.

tower_host.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower host.
body: tower_host
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name to use for the host.
variables: not required, default: undefined. # Variables to use for the host. Use '@' for a file.
enabled: not required, default: true. # If the host should be enabled.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource.
inventory: required, default: undefined. # Inventory the host should be made a member of.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
description: not required, default: null. # The description to use for the host.

tower_inventory.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower inventory.
body: tower_inventory
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
name: required, default: undefined. # The name to use for the inventory.
variables: not required, default: null. # Inventory variables. Use '@' to get from file.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
organization: required, default: undefined. # Organization the inventory belongs to.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
description: not required, default: null. # The description to use for the inventory.
tower_job_cancel
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
job_id: required, default: undefined. # ID of the job to cancel
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
fail_if_not_running: not required, default: false. # Fail loudly if the job_id does not reference a running job.
tower_job_launch
credential: not required, default: null. # Credential to use for job, only used if prompt for credential is set.
use_job_endpoint: not required, default: false. # Disable launching jobs from job template.
job_template: required, default: undefined. # Name of the job_template to use.
tags: not required, default: null. # Specific tags to use for from playbook.
extra_vars: not required, default: null. # Extra_vars to use for the job_template. Prepend '@' if a file.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
job_type: not required, default: null. # Job_type to use for the job, only used if prompt for job_type is set.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
limit: not required, default: null. # Limit to use for the job_template.
inventory: not required, default: null. # Inventory to use for the job, only used if prompt for inventory is set.
job_explanation: not required, default: null. # Job explanation field.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
tower_job_list
status: not required, default: null. # Only list jobs with this status.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
page: not required, default: null. # Page number of the results to fetch.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
all_pages: not required, default: false. # Fetch all the pages and return a single result.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
query: not required, default: null. # Query used to further filter the list of jobs. {"foo":"bar"} will be passed at ?foo=bar

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_job_template.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower job_template.
body: tower_job_template
network_credential: not required, default: null. # The network_credential to use for the job_template.
description: not required, default: null. # Description to use for the job_template.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
ask_inventory: not required, default: false. # Propmt user for inventory on launch.
job_type: required, default: undefined. # The job_type to use for the job_template.
ask_job_type: not required, default: false. # Prompt user for job type on launch.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
skip_tags: not required, default: null. # The skip_tags to use for the job_template.
playbook: required, default: undefined. # Playbook to use for the job_template.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
ask_tags: not required, default: false. # Prompt user for job tags on launch.
host_config_key: not required, default: null. # Allow provisioning callbacks using this host config key.
machine_credential: not required, default: null. # Machine_credential to use for the job_template.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
ask_credential: not required, default: false. # Prompt user for credential on launch.
name: required, default: undefined. # Name to use for the job_template.
job_tags: not required, default: null. # The job_tags to use for the job_template.
verbosity: not required, default: null. # Control the output level Ansible produces as the playbook runs.
project: required, default: undefined. # Project to use for the job_template.
state: not required, default: present. # Desired state of the resource.
ask_extra_vars: not required, default: false. # Prompt user for extra_vars on launch.
extra_vars_path: not required, default: null. # Path to the extra_vars yaml file.
inventory: not required, default: null. # Inventory to use for the job_template.
limit: not required, default: null. # A host pattern to further constrain the list of hosts managed or affected by the playbook
forks: not required, default: null. # The number of parallel or simultaneous processes to use while executing the playbook.
cloud_credential: not required, default: null. # Cloud_credential to use for the job_template.
become_enabled: not required, default: false. # Should become_enabled.

tower_job_wait.description: Wait for Ansible Tower job to finish.
body: tower_job_wait
min_interval: not required, default: 1. # Minimum interval in seconds, to request an update from Tower.
job_id: required, default: undefined. # ID of the job to monitor.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
max_interval: not required, default: 30. # Maximum interval in seconds, to request an update from Tower.
timeout: not required, default: null. # Maximum time in seconds to wait for a job to finish.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.

tower_project.description: create, update, or destroy Ansible Tower projects

scm_branch: not required, default: null. # The branch to use for the scm resource.
description: not required, default: null. # Description to use for the project.
tower_host: not required, default: null. # URL to your Tower instance.
scm_update_on_launch: not required, default: false. # Before an update to the local repository before launching a job with this project.
scm_clean: not required, default: false. # Remove local modifications before updating.
scm_type: not required, default: manual. # Type of scm resource.
scm_delete_on_update: not required, default: false. # Remove the repository completely before updating.
tower_username: not required, default: null. # Username for your Tower instance.
tower_password: not required, default: null. # Password for your Tower instance.
tower_config_file: not required, default: null. # Path to the Tower config file. See notes.
name: required, default: null. # Name to use for the project.

tower_verify_ssl: not required, default: true. # Dis/allow insecure connections to Tower. If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites using self-signed certificates.
